name: Firewatch
description: Firewatch is a single-player first-person mystery set in the Wyoming wilderness, where your only emotional lifeline is the person on the other end of a handheld radio.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or higher 64bit Processor: Intel Core i3 2.00 GHz or AMD equivalent Memory: 6 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 450 or higher with 1GB Memory DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 4 GB available space

reviews.review_text: 'What if a controlled fire gets out of control?' 'Then someone gets fired!'    This game is art in its own. But as art goes, probably not for everyone. The whole gameplay is story + dialog driven, with a touch of exploration. Which also means, there is not much action, the focus is clearly on atmosphere and the protagonists.  You have a troublesome past which you fled from and the woman on the other side as well. You try to make your job at the end of the world while talking about what you see, do and also have experienced in your past.    This game...

Firwatch  Firewatch is an enjoyable 'first-person mystery' by a small team of folks who know what they are doing.  Applying the 'walking simulator' is not inaccurate, but that may be too dismissive of the refined experience Firewatch offers.  Much walking through a nicely realized, highly stylized forest environment is involved, but the most notable ingredient of the game is your character's interaction with the other main character via portable radio - one of the finer examples of such interaction in the video game medium.  The game starts by building a backstory of your character via text, allowing you to make several choices - an effective technique to help you identify with your character. These choices are later reflected in dialogue (although they do not, as far as I know, have a significant impact on the plot). The dialogue mechanic, the control over dialogue responses effectively facilitates immersion and the dialogue is very well voiced.  Firewatch does a good job at pacing, at maintaining suspense. Although, you can choose at times to wander off on a few detours and delay story progression. There's a decent amount of optional secrets and details to discover, but not very many - if short on time, don't worry about them and just stick to the goals at hand, as you won't miss much. The game can last about 4-8 hours depending on how much you stray/dawdle.  Perhaps the most questionable aspect of the game is the hype and marketing that emphasizes the mystery. There certainly is mystery, and it's pretty good, but many, perhaps even most, might be surprised and perhaps disappointed that the story progression doesn't match quite the expectations they had. Although I did feel a mild sense of being the victim of misdirection, I liked the story, and the game.  The other perhaps surprising but astute design principle here is what isn't explicitly shown. The (visual and auditory) presentation is such that much is left to the imagination and exposition is trickle-fed. A cynic might accuse this paradigm of being a cost saving measure. And maybe it is. But, it is effective at engaging the player's mind.  I recommend Firewatch as a short but good interactive mystery experience, especially if it's on sale.

I had high hopes for this game after I saw the 15 minutes review gameplay on YouTube. I didn't even mind the high price tag for the supposedly short 6 hours of gameplay as I was expecting a good mystery for my character to solve. But all in all, I was pretty disappointed with how the game unfolded.   + Beautiful graphics. + Very atmospheric. + Good soundtrack. + Excellent voice acting for the witty dialogues. + Engaging story at the start and towards the middle.  - Story didn't really deliver. It started off strong and then just fell flat / boring towards the end. Some parts were predictable. - Very short (expected at least 6 hours of gameplay, got only 4.5hours).  - No consequences of your dialogue choices.  - No replay value. - Price tag is too high for its current content. - Linear. Since this is more like a walking simulator, I was expecting a bigger map, if not an open world. - Expected a good mystery but got   a flirty woman on the radio instead  .  Buy it if you don't mind a walking simulator with a subpar storyline, but I simply cannot recommend it at its current price; there's just not enough content to justify the price tag. Get it only when it's heavily discounted.  EDIT: Like a lot of people, I wish there's a Neutral button that I could give it. It's not a bad game per se, it has its merits and I did enjoy some parts of it. But with its current $20 base price (less in my regional Steam store), I got about 4 hours of gameplay. Of a mediocre story line. With an abrupt 'WTF' ending that I didn't enjoy / like.   My Rating: 5/10

First off, let's get it out of the way and say that yes, the game is extremely short. It took me about three hours to play all the way through the story. With no incentive to replay it, the game might not be worth the asking price for many people who read this review. If you don't want to pay $20 for a 3 hour experience, then that is fine, and respectable.  However, the experience that you're buying here is something unlike other games you've played. Firewatch, no matter what all the naysayers believe, is a very groundbreaking game. It did something no other game has ever done for me: make me feel like I was talking to an actual human being when I had conversations with Delilah as Henry. The connection you build with her is something unlike anything you'll see in another game. It just feels so... real. She feels like a real person. I believe that the feeling is amplified by the fact that you never really see a physical representation of Delilah in the game. You only ever speak to her through your handy walkie-talkie, which means the only thing I ever associated her with, was with a real, breathing human.  The story that Firewatch tells is also an extremely believable, heart-wrenching, and yet heart-warming one. I'll not go into details or spoilers, but let's just say that the story is a very human mystery, and has a few twists that leave you pondering every single thing you ever did in the game, and wondering how it was all connected. The story wasn't something that will completely blow your mind and make you rethink your life, but it is just that hint of subtlety that makes it so enjoyable. It just feels so real, man.  I believe that the price tag on Firewatch is worthwhile. The beauty of the landscape in which the game is set isn't really comparable to very many other games. The world is exquisitely detailed, and the art style does a lot for the overall atmosphere the game is going for. Photorealism wasn't something that the developers were going for, as the art has a very cartoonish, animated feeling - and yet all of the finer details in the world are still there, such as print on the back of some of the books found in the game that can actually be read. The environment will immerse you in your surroundings, and if not for your map and compass and Delilah's guidance, it would be quite easy to get lost in the extensive wilderness in which the game is set. On top of that, the voice acting in the game is probably some of the best you'll ever hear. For such a small title, it is astonishing how well voice acted it was. The voice acting certainly helped to add to the immersion of the world, but it also helps justify the price of the title, as quality like that can't come cheap.  In the end, if you're looking for a quick, hearty game that you want to make you feel something, then this game is definitely worth your time, and your money. If you don't have the cash to fork out for a game you'll probably only ever play once, then I don't think this title is for you.

This game has great voice acting, great atmosphere and the main characters are very likeable, but the story is so so, especialy the ending is a bit of an anticlimax. The biggest problem i have with this game is that its too expensive, 18€ for 3 hours of game time, and that is without rushing it, I do not recommend it for that price.

A truly beautiful game which tackles very mature themes like depression, anxiety, loneliness and paranoia. I'd like to keep this short because it really needs to be experienced. Great visuals, amazing sound design, excellent storytelling and stellar voiceover-work. It's probably not for everyone, though.

I wanted to love this game. i was invested for the first 3.5 hours and then the ending hit. the ending kills the game. there is no pay off to anything in the story  edit* the ending is bad depending on how you viewed the game, if you viewed the game as a mystery or a thriller. you will be thoroughly disappointed. but if you played the game just for the relationships and interactions between the main characters than you may be fine with the ending

It's hard to review this. I enjoyed the experience while it was happening. With that said the final thought is 'wanting more'.  Wanting more from it's abrupt and dissapointing ending. Wanting more development of the plot. Wanting more development of the relationship between the two characters. Wanting for your choices to matter and for the gameplay mechanics to have a meaning. I finished it in less than four hours. For a game, any game, that's very very little. You get a taste of everything this game could have been but you never get fed.

I don't really care enough to write reviews, but this game I found genuinely dissapointing. I saw it on sale for about $16 the day before it's release. I remember seing the E3 presentation of the game and thought 'Hey, seems like it could be a nice mystery game with decent decision making that would effect the outcome along with some rather pleasent to listen to voice acting'. So I had an interest in this title. But, did it fare to my expectations? Nope. Here's why.  Now I am going to avoid spoilers, because I respect that some will want to give this a shot themselves, but I strongly recommend waiting for a sale. Like $5.00 sale.   I'm going to start off with the pros, because despite my over-all disappointed there are some commendable attributes.  Pros: +Voice acting - This is definitly the golden prize of the game. Interactions between Henry (Rich Sommer) and Delilah (Cissy Jones) are engaging and rather entertaining. It definilty does a good job and genuinely making you feel involved in the characters relationship.  +Soundtrack - The ambient acoustic guitar throughout the game never got tedious and kept me enthralled and quite relaxed.   +Art Style - A rather pretty lookng game, I definilty sense heavy inspiration of Team Fortress 2 especially in player model (A modded asset from Team Fortress 2). Environment is pretty to look at. But ultimately feels kind of lifeless.  +Story (Acts one and two) The sense of mystery surrounding the game specifically in the first two acts, definilty made a rather intense on-the-egde of your seat impact. It was what drove me to keep playing till the end. But, this is where I get into the cons.  Cons: -Not enough depth - I thoroughly enjoyed the first 40 minutes of playing. I initially felt the game could've had a lot to offer in terms of exploration. I mean, look at the map when you first get into the lookout. It seams plentiful, like there'd be a lot to find and discover. But unfortunately there's northing really to keep from following the rather linear pathway to keep the story rolling. I didn't get the flashlight till near the end of the game and I pretty much didn't even need it.   -Lifeless - When you start off and come across an Elk and then a tree scratched to ♥♥♥♥ by a Grizzly, I thought 'Huh, maybe there'll be an encounter with a Grizzly'. Nope. Asside from the gran-total 3 npcs to come across, there is very little wildlife present in these woods. Even though the game warns of these encounters, they never occure. Ever.  -Length - Having finished the game in only 3 hours, I finally understand Angry Joes contempt for short ♥♥♥ titles, I've often avoided them because they aren't worth the asking price. I honesltly hoped this would've been a bit longer. 8 - 9 hours atleast.   -Illusion of choice - One thing the game did interestingly was the choices of dialogue between Henry and Delilah but ultimiately this was meaningless and has little impact on end-game. Even the text based intro makes no difference whatsoever except for a naked sketch of you depending on how you choose pose. That's it.  -Ending sucked - A game presented like this, at least could've had multiple endings.... There's only two and they're both exactly the ♥♥♥♥ing same.   All in all, I give this game a 4 out of 10. It's not really worth $20, if on sale for like $5:00 and you enjoy dialogue heavy games then maybe give it a shot. But for the most part, it's pretty 'meh'.
A work of art. A great novel.  A nice escape.
I found a turtle and named it Turt Reynolds. 10/10

This game made me go through an emotional rollercoaster, my imagination made the tale a lot scarier than it actually was.  But rarely am I left feeling this.. empty after a game. I connected to the two main character in this game. I giggled over jokes and..the ending made me long for more.

Firewatch is Gorgeous, but the Fire Never Rises. Minor spoilers, but no dead give aways.  First off let me say that the game is gorgeous, and its good; but it isnt great. The art is really neat and looks great for what it is. The music is captivating and goes great with the setting. That being said, the plot falls short. I felt like I was playing 'Explore the Woods Simulator 2016' more than a mystery game. Sure there is a mystery but it never really is explained it kind of just develops out of nowhere. One minute you are at point A. and suddenly you are at Z with very little in between. It was frightening to play thinking that there was more to come but it just never happened. The most intense moment in the game is a semi stealthy exploration of an unchartered camp which, in reality, isn't even a threatening part of the game. I was giddy in the middle. I felt like the game might have a scooby doo ending where theres a villian behind everything trying to scare away people to secure his treasure or something silly, but it didn't even come close to that. In fact, you never even really encounter a villian. Like I said, its a decent game, not worth $17 though. Maybe grab it on sale and kocnk it out one day. Just don't go in with hopes of a great story.   Would not reccomened for full retail. Pick it up on sale and enjoy it.

How to enjoy firewatch: 1. Prepare enough time to play it in a single sitting (~4-5 hours) 2. Turn off the map marker in the options (so that your map and compass are actually important) 3. Take your time, explore, there are a lot of details and you can usually radio them in. 4. Don't run, unless you feel that it suits the urgency of the situation. 5. There are no wrong answers, try a different approach in your next playthrough. 6. Enjoy a 'strange summer break' with Henry and Delilah.

Difficult to know whether to recommend this game or not, because in my mind it's not really a 'game'. I guess I'd call it an interactive story, or experience. There's really not much of anything in the way of actual gameplay. You mostly wander around trying to find your way between various waypoints with the help of a compass and map. So it really kind of depends what you're looking for.  Overall, it's very well done. The story is compelling as you play, though I did feel the ending was a little weak. The graphics and general feel throughout are great. If being alone in the forest while experiencing a compelling story in a beautifully realized world appeals to you then you'll probably enjoy it. Just don't expect a ton of traditional gameplay. It's really more of a visual novel/interactive movie.

Exploring the environment is interesting at first but there is a lot of retreading with only small new areas opening each day.Woods are almost barren of life and things to explore. Story builds up only to end with a 'oh, that's it?'. Really, the only decent part is the banter between the two major characters.

I just finished the game and I have to say that it was very good. The story takes you and gets you so into it you just can't stop playing. One big problem I had with it though is I finished it within 4 hours of playtime... I need so much more I really wanted the game to focus more on the survival aspect but sadly it didnt. Dont let this review stop you from purchasing the game because dont get me wrong it was beautifully made, I just needed so much more...

I wanted to like this game and for a good half of the game I actually did. I really did like some snippets of this game, but it wasn't enough to win me over. When I got further into the game and eventually beat it, I felt pretty empty and betrayed. Firewatch builds up a pretty interesting story and characters just to ruin it at the end and throughout.   What I liked: -The voice acting was very convincing and felt very genuine. Very charming game. -This game made me feel emotions, joy, sadness, suspense, something I crave from games but rarely get. -The visuals are gorgeous, quite possibly one of the most beautiful games I've played. (I've spent alot of time taking screenshots) -The soundtrack was beautiful and played at very appropriate moments. Guided the players' emotions.  What I did not like: -The game was very linear and more often than not did not feel more open, rather it had the illusion of being open. -The story fell flat on its face toward the end and halted to a stop abruptly. A giant build up just for nothing (very disappointed personally) -Player choices did not matter at all. the game doesn't take any turns if you choose a certain line of dialogue. (at least thats what I gathered, I may be wrong) -Very short, I usually enjoy short games, for example Dishonored. With this game, it was too short for its own good and could have been longer so the story met a satisfactory ending. -Price tag is a little too high for this game, I felt like I paid too much for what I got. -Boring achievements. Congrats you did something mandatory to finishing the game!  Some of my additional opinions: -The main characters, Henry and Delilah, should have tried to fix each others issues rather than continue to just point them out, some character progression would be nice. -Their chemistry got a bit stale for me, but never got annoying.   Conclusion: I don't want to tell you if you should get it or not because I don't feel like I have the authority to do so. Take my points into consideration and come to your own conclusion. Because I can't give a neutral review on steam I will give it a negative review since I'm teetering more on not recommending it. I don't hate it since it did give me some enjoyment even if it was followed by disappointing. I really wish there was a better ending to Firewatch. Maybe wait until a sale.   Thanks for your time!

Was there content removed? Hints through out the game of different stories yet they never appeared through out the game, through out my time I explored everywhere and compelted with 100% and still only managed 5 hours game time  Delilah   The over heard radio messsage from Delilah, never went anywhere    Fenced off area   what was that about, red herring or did they remove content at last minute and made the Dad the bad guy

Well, this was a mistake. Was looking for something to fill the void after Life is Strange and was recommended this. Though the voice acting is amazing, the story was quite dull and had a terrible ending. I ended up walking for 4 hours, looking forward to dialog to fill the tedious vagivation and boring gameplay.

Completed the Game, took me 5,5 hours (minus the food and drink breaks). Gotta say, Well worth it. It was amazing exprience. Kept me interested from the beginning till end. Great voice acting, great visuals, great ambient sounds. Performs really well, no crashes no issues for me under Linux.  Don't wanna spoil the story but i think the pacing was perfect, no story stretching or anything.   10/10

Firewatch is a prime example on how to hype a game, that is decent, but really nothing juicy or groundbreaking in any way. It's a walking simulator through and through, but with outstanding voice acting.  + GREAT voice acting + decent art style + a little bit interesting  - short (you've seen it all in less than 4 hrs) - no replay value - no decisions - linear - not worth 20 bucks, maybe 5-10... - weak ending  If you can pick it up for less than 10 dollar, it may be worth it, but prepare yourself to be bored a bit.  If you hide your location on the map it's a bit more interesting.

Well, it started out quite interesting, but the more you played, the more it became an entirely different game called 'Hiking Simulator'. THe scenery was quite nice to look at and the dialogues weren't that bad, but the plot was thin and unconvincing and the ending was anticlimatic. The promised 'mystery' wasn't very mysteriuos and everything that could have developed into an interesting plot was cut short during one of the endless hikes. All in all I have to say that I was quite disappointed and wouldn't recommend it to anyone, who expects more than hiking through a nice virtual lanndscape.

Here's the thing. This ISN'T a game. It is a creative way to tell a story, much like The Begginers guide and The Stanley Parable. There isn't actually any real gameplay, it's just you walking around and clicking until the next part of the story comes up. It is most certainly not worth 20 dollars. Hell, probably not even 10. I might pay 2 or 3. Just watch the story on youtube, don't waste your money

This game is beautiful, in more ways than one and one of the most thoroughly enjoyable games to play. Your only interaction is with a voice over the radio, yet by the end you feel like you've grown closer to the voice on the other end than anyone else in your life. There's great humor, banter and some really serious moments, with decisions that create internal conflict. This is branching narrative at its best. If you're down for an adventure, a visual feast for your eyes, a bit of mystery and a good companion to talk to, then take up post for Firewatch. Two Forks Tower is waiting for you.

The game was excellent at first.. the first part was kind of like a choose your own adventure game. And then.. the choices got harder and harder. And by the time that i was actually able to walk around i was fully invested in Henry's story. I will admit, the scenery was quite lovely and the dialogue between Henry and Delilah was entertaining. However, i dont think it was worth its price. If you do decide to get this game, wait until it is on sale. I felt there was not enough content for it to be worth its full listing price.. or even its sale price (which was 17.00 when i got it.)  Sad to say, i ended up not enjoying much of the scenery because i was glued to the map the entire time, making sure i was going the right direction. There was all this suspense towards the end.. and i was floored the entire game long, waiting for something amazing to happen something to be revealed.. some deadly secret everyone was keeping from me. But at the end of the game.. six hours in.. the ending left me feeling dissapointed. I needed more answers.. the abrupt way it ended just felt.. wrong.. the whole time i expected more.. but there was nothing. Honestly, the game end made me feel like someone ripped the middle and parts of the end out of a really good book and then just left me with the scraps.  Not to mention i spent nearly an hour stuck on a set of rocks, glitching out with invisible walls which didn't seem like they should be there at all. Why let me climb a rock and then not go back down the other side when its touching the ground. It was rather frustrating.  In the end.. this game is a walking simulator.. which i tend to enjoy when they have a story.. but this one.. felt dull and lifeless. I mean.. it wasn't really bad because i was glued to the screen the entire time i was playing.. but the ending.. just felt like a huge cop out. So.. in the end.. i would say only play this game if you are looking for nothing exciting to happen.
I really like this game, the story is very exiting, the characters are awesome and the graphic and the sounds are really good,too.
Must be one of the shortest games I've completed for £15, but such a beautiful one I don't even regret it.

Good story, i beat the game SLOWLY over 2.5 hours my first time,  If it was longer its a really good game. But its SO short! if you have 20$ to throw away for 2 hours of fun, get it. BUT if you're looking for the 5-6 hours it says it is on these websites which were prolly paid by the company to say it was that long. look elsewhere.  Pro:  Good storyline  Fun game ran fine for my with a 3820 CPU with a 980 TI graphics card.  Con:  WAY WAY too short  too expensive for the time only 1 ending. multiple ways to get there but only 1 ending.

Firewatch  is a great walking simulator. So great, in fact, that many gamers (including myself) at times wanted it to breach the walls and actually have more 'gaming' elements.  This game really has the whole package; the artwork, music, voice acting, animation and atmosphere are all expertly crafted. The storyline is moving, to say the least.   The two major shortcomings in my mind are 1) the game is quite short (3 hours to 'finish' the story), and 2) there is little replay value.  I will elaborate on both.  Although the twenty dollar price tag has become fairly standard for quality walking simulators (a la  Gone Home  or  Dear Esther , among others), you only get a measly few hours of enjoyment out of it. The hours are top quality, though. After I was done, I kept asking myself why they couldn't have added in more achievements or side quests to fill out the time and add more incentive to replay. Sure, there are little 'easter eggs' of sorts littered throughout the map, but its certainly not enough for me to justify the large-ish price tag.  Achievements would incentivize this; for example, I earned all the achievements in my first 3 hour playthrough.    Beyond that, everything is great. The story is wonderful and the experience is divine.   Just realize that this is a walking simulator proper. They may tease you with finding an axe, but there is no game here. Thats ok, but I think some of us wanted it to go to that next level.  It was most likely created to be a short experience on purpose, though. For example, while the map feels large and sandboxy at first, it quickly shows that it is quite limited. Once again, thats ok, but it merits being mentioned. The map is not as open-world as it may have us think. Its a series of 'tunnels'. Very beautiful tunnels.   Pros:  +Stunning artwork and scenery +Truly great voice acting +Outstanding story-telling +Music is excellent +Its short, but what is there is powerful   Cons:  -Its short, with a fairly steep price-tag (albeit par for the genre) -I wanted more 'game', but thats like asking for more guns in  Minecraft  (hey devs take that as a compliment, because you really made something wonderful that could go in any direction) -The map really needs more life added. I didn't see a single bug-swarm for example. I could go on and on about this, but you get the idea.   Walking simulator fans really need to play this for the experience.  Even with only 3 hours of play time at this moment, I don't regret a single dollar spent.
Not worth what is costs.
Firewatch is perfectly named because the title fully describes the experience of playing it.

I was ready to call this like playing a Pixar film, but I feel as though it would've been better if it WAS a Pixar film and not a $20 3 hour interactive narrative. Any feeling of replayability you feel you might get is thrown out the window once you finish it.  This hurts because I was really looking forward to this. The characters are very likeable and the Wyoming wilderness is stylized with some beautiful vistas and scenery. The team did an excellent job of building an area, but it doesn't feel as fleshed out as it should've and ultimately underwhelming.
THAT'S IT?! Good fun game graphics awesome but its too short. Not worth $20 ,but if its around $8 its worth

Not really worth the money. The story begins very well, but dissapoints at the end. The graphics look nice, but you won't really see much more than in the pictures that are shown here on Steam. That also counts for the places, as the game world is very small and you can only follow special tracks.  The only good thing is the voice acting, but that alone is just not worth it.

Firewatch is, in many senses, not a video game.  I suppose I best could classify Firewatch as a 'book game'.  Before I continue any farther, the tl;dr version is that I recommend Firewatch whole-heartedly, and I enjoyed it immensely. Some of the climbing was in some ways a little tedious, but in otherways added a lot more deliberate-ness to the situation. It felt more... immersive. It was a tediousness that felt a part of the game rather than a flaw in it, which for me excused the issue. Other than that, I loved Firewatch.  Anyway.  Firewatch is a fantastic game overall. The choices are interesting and feel personable, the characters are relateable and instantly likeable, and feel like real 3D people with great depth.  And that's really what Firewatch is about. People. It is almost entirely about your interaction with the Voice At The End Of The Radio. Other than that, there are people around that, that affect the situation and the topic and your responses to the VATEOTR, who are always on your character's mind, and in turn, on your mind, but ultimately it is about your interaction with this one, other person.  And it is fascinating. It's so enjoyable to talk with her. Her responses are real and sometimes funny and I laughed and I cried and I enjoyed the game all the way through. At the time of writing I finished the story in about four hours, but I will definitely be playing it again, and it was four hours well spent.  One of my favourite parts which sets almost the entire mood for your conversation with the VATEOTR, is the scenery. The world you're put in is absolutely gorgeous, and an absolute constant pleasure to be in. It is styleized in such a gorgeous way that makes the game feel truly authentic.  In essence, I loved Firewatch, and I will play it again.  10/10
While I personally thought the ending was pretty weak I still overall enjoyed the journey the game takes you on. However you probably want to wait untill its drops to 5-10$ before buying it.

Although the game is great at the beginning, the ending is so disappointing it leaves a bad taste and a desire to have the few hours you invested in this game back.  Pros: -Beautiful atmosphere -Good acting -Believable, lovable and realistic characters -Great monologues  Cons: -If you're here for the mystery and the plot, this game is not for you. -Less than okay gameplay -A very disappointing ending. It feels like the writers weren't sure how to finish the story, and made some quick choices in order to make their life easy. -Soundtrack? What soundtrack?  If there was no mystery and no try to make this game 'interesting', this entire review would have looked different. The game was exploring a very intriguing idea of two regular people who need to escape their daily lives and have some time for themselves to think and accept the bad things that just happened to them.  If you really want, I recommend to buy it on sale or just watch a Let's Play on youtube.

Firewatch left me wanting more. This was the first time I've ever played a game like this and even though there's not much action and a lot of walking, I really enjoyed it. The dialog between the two charactors is very well done. Unfortuneatly there is zero reason to play through more than once as the game is very linear. Its more like an interactive movie than a game.

I'm at bit disappointed to be honest. I've got an ROG laptop with 8gb ram, 1gb dedicated video ram, an Invidia GTX860m, and I've had the video portion of the game lock up completely on me several times just within the first 30 mins of play. It seems to affect just the video as the screen freezes but which allows the game to continue behind the screen This seems to be related to the use of the walkie talkie .   I've had to turn all graphics and goodies down to the bare minimums just to get somewhat smooth framerates. I know I don't have the latest and greatest Alienware or such, but for a 15 month old gaming laptop, I think it should run better than that. I have no trouble with Fallout 4 or other such games. I'm hoping for updates that will allow a decent play of this game as the premise, setting, playstyle sounds awesome.   As I cannot skip the recommendation part of the review, I must select No due to it being unplayable for me. =(

Good game, but very short. Luckly it was reasonably cheap. It was very linear and there is really nothing to figure out as far as puzzles go. Its really too bad, if this was part I or an early release with more in the works or something I could reccomend it. As it is I can't tell you to buy this 3.5 hour long game.

Ok, 1st thing to notice in the game to those using Laptops with Dual Graphics or PC with Dual Graphics or anyone using it, you need to force intergrate the game to run on NVIDIA and not on Intel. Thus the reason people will get some weird frames.  Now for the game. Its beautiful not just the graphic but the music, the ambience, the atmostphere and the story itself is......Ok not going to spoil but the opening intro of the game is so DARK and SAD!!! I guarantee you that all the 'negative' reviews on this are from people who:  A) Don't like games with lots of walking  B) Don't like games that are mainly about story more than gameplay  C) Are telling you it's not worth $20.  And to adress those issues, I say:  To both A and B... Why even buy the game, then? It should be pretty clear by the videos, trailers, and description that this game is mainly about story telling and environment. Not gameplay. Negative reviews written because of that purpose hold no water, as they're biased right out of the starting gate.  To C... Eh. It really depends how much you like story and environment-based games. If you really, really like them, this is definitely worth the $20. It has a good amount of replayability, as most of the chat options you choose are pretty obvious choices between being a total ♥♥♥♥ and being a good friend, so you can replay all you want to change your relationship with Delilah.  Look, I'll be blunt. There's no multiple endings. I don't want you to buy this game if you're in it for finding all the endings. But the different dialogue paths are certainly intersting. You can restart any day, so you don't have to play through the entire game again to change one dialogue option (Although some days are pretty long, so you might have to play through a bit if you're changing a dialogue option towards the end of one of them...).  Is the dialogue, environment, and storytelling good?  Yes. In fact it's some of the best I've seen in any game, really. I'm not exaggerating. The reactions seem very real, and at times I would think or even say something the characters were going to say in a couple seconds because, well, the reactions are very human and not faked at all. If your character sees something horribly unsettling, he's not going to be all heroic like, 'Do not fear! I will... yada yada', he's going to freak the ♥♥♥♥ out.  Like I said, it's sort of a walking simulator. But don't mind that. Please don't take that as a negative at all, unless you really, REALLY hate walking. The environment is so beautiful, you'll totally forget how long it took your to walk one place to another. There's also a jogging toggle without a stamina limit too, if you're not the type to want to stare at painstakingly crafted, beautiful landscapes (you monster).  There's not many characters either, which is good if you ask me. It helps the game really develop all of them, although I will say some relationship statuses are sort of forced on you through huge time-skips, where things sort of happened without your consent. And some of the dialogue options can be variants of the same thing, making you say something you don't want to, one way or the other. But those are basically the only bad things about it. No map glitches or texture bugs to be found.  Oh and last bit of advice, there's no way to get a game-over. No way to die or anything... Which kinda helps actually, since it makes the characters' reactions to dangerous scenarios more realistic and less 'Oh, well, if I die its no big deal anyways'. So if you want a game where you have to worry about dying now and then, and have the tension of danger over your shoulder... Look elsewhere.  Overall, 9/10. It's a bit short and is really only a great game for the people who are really into the genre of environment/narrative-based storytelling games, but believe me, for those people, it's a must-have. Please don't pass this up because of a few harsh words if you're really into the genre.

Imagine life as a secluded fire lookout in a national forrest. There is nothing around you for miles, except nature and gently-cut trails. Your job is simply to identify, observe, and track wildfires as they move through the area. Sounds pretty mundane, right?  Well, you're not wrong. There isn't much action aside from the occasional rock-climbing. That said, this game isn't about action. It's all about the story.  Firewatch is an interactive story, more than a traditional game. Thankfully, this is Firewatch's strength. It is well-written, and the voice-acting is excellent. There are times when you can get absorbed with taking in the scenery, and others where the scenery is blurring by as Firewatch dials up the tension. Even the casual controls help keep your mind off what your hands are doing, and focussed on what you're experiencing.  I've seen a lot of complaints that it's short (I finished in just under 5 hours), but there's no point to dragging it out. The narative is what is presented, not the mechanics. Would I say it's 'a fun game?' Maybe not. But it's definitely an enjoyable experience, even if it's only for a few hours.  Oh, and the graphics are gorgeous. I love the art style. I almost feel it's what the Borderlands games could have/should have been.   TL;DR:  Loved it. A great experience, from start to finish. But if you want to really enjoy it, you'll need to let go of expectations of testing your survival skills in the wild, and just let the story guide you through the experience.   Pros:  A well-executed story, beautiful visuals, really engaging  Cons:  A few dialog continuity hiccups, seems like some areas are wasted opportunities for exploration (but that could be a throw-back to traditional expectations)

Was looking forward to this game for a long, long time. Really wanted it to be good. And it is good, at certain things. The first hour or so of the game is wonderful, thanks to the chemistry between Henry and Delilah. It's some of the best writing and voice acting I've seen in a long time.  Then it turns into an episode of the X-Files, and all the chemistry between the two leads vanishes.   I'm not going to spoil what twists and turns the story takes. Instead, I'll point out that the story starts out great and ends up falling flat, largely because of two things:  1. The pacing. The game starts with a slow burn. You're learning about the two characters, about the world, and occasionally a weird thing here, a weird thing there. That's fine. Then, all of a sudden, there is an abrupt turn into crazytown. I felt like I was just starting to settle into the groove of Hank 'n Delilah, when all hell breaks loose. Suddenly Hank and Delilah are bemoaning [spoilery thing I won't mention] plaguing them ALL SUMMER LONG, and I'm like 'Wait, what? All summer? It was Day 2 of summer ten minutes ago. Then you jumped to Day 30 something, then Day 40 something, and now we're here.' The game doesn't actually build a solid foundation between Hank and Delilah; it pulls the equivalent of 'Two months later...' and expects that time to add weight to the proceedings. It doesn't. You can't just skip months of time and then have the characters say 'Oh, all that time we've spent together' as if it means something. It doesn't.   2. The quality of the writing. The first hour is phenomenal. Hank and Delilah have charmingly awkward conversations about their pasts, about the job. You have opportunities to press a little, or hold back, and you begin to shape your relationship with this total stranger who is also your only lifeline. Once the game takes the aforementioned sharp turn into crazytown, though, every conversation basically becomes:  Hank: I found a thing. Delilah: You found a thing?! What the hell? Are you sure it's a thing? Hank: I am certain it's a thing. Delilah: I can't believe it's a thing. I don't like this, Hank. Hank: I don't like it either. I'm going to keep looking. Delilah: We've got to find out about the thing.  Relationship building? Basically gone. Character development? Not so much. Sense of humor? Vanished. As soon as the plot kicks in, the core pillar of this game - the relationship between Hank and Delilah - is sucked dry of everything that made it interesting. As soon as the story takes center stage, they become a *stunningly* boring pair.  I don't even care about the actual plot. Weird stuff happens, more weird stuff happens, you're given a seemingly plausible explanation for some of it, the end. By the time the credits ran, I couldn't have cared less about any of it; I was still just wondering what had happened to those interesting characters I met in the first hour, and why they were replaced with Blandy McBlanderton and the Blandtime Band.  What a waste. So much potential, and the developers clearly know how to write compelling characters; I just can't understand why they would abandon those characters to focus on a completely run-of-the-mill story instead.

I’ve actually been looking forward to Firewatch for years now, long before it was announced. Once I heard that the head devs for two of my favorite games, Walking Dead Season 1 and Mark of the Ninja, had founded their own studio I knew I had to play their first game. Firewatch didn’t disappoint me at all.  Firewatch is a narrative driven adventure game that has you play as Henry, a man working in a national park looking out for forest fires, seemingly trying to get away from his normal life. His only real contact to anyone else is his superior, Delilah, who’s stationed in another outpost miles away. The game focuses on how you develop your relationship with them, as well what kind of guy Henry is. There’s also some good amounts of exploration as well. The dialogue is fantastic and reactive, and you will probably make a habit of calling in everything to Delilah just so you can have more of their interactions. It's overall a fantastic character piece video game and the first ten minutes alone illustrate this from the get-go.  While the plot is set in stone, their relationship and who Henry is is not. The plot is also engaging and has an air of real mystery to it. The ending is ultimately quite satisfying and bittersweet, practically all loose ends are tied up and it can end on a melancholy yet hopeful note. It also has really good pacing, people may whine that its short, but some gamers just don’t seem to appreciate tightly-paced games. (And really its not that short, it took me almost five hours to complete it, also give me quality over quantity any day.)  Also the game is gorgeous and walking around the forest is great. The soundtracks is also really good too and adds to the atmosphere.  Overall Firewatch is a great adventure game and while I’m still mulling it over if it’s one of my favorite games of all time, its most definitely going to be one of my GOTY.

This game hit me hard and i think i finally figured out why.   Delilah represents something many online gamers have experienced. Delilah is that person you connect with in an MMO or other online world and you feel you could hang out with/ date/ marry irl. While the game is fresh and fun and you're exploring together, the banter and chemistry gets stronger over time, only communicating by voice. You start to wonder if this is a person you could spend time with in real life despite not even knowing what they look like- but you don't know if the other person is thinking the same. As the game dies down, people quit, and the end draws near for various reasons- you casually test these waters. The other person likes you as a partner in this virtual world, but is clearly not into the idea of meeting irl. Once the game is over (the semester begins as summer ends?) you aren't quite sure if you'll ever talk to that person again. You even ask if they'll play again on their next break ('next summer') but they sound like this will be their last big foray into video games. It's a sad but very real portrait of how many of us can envelope ourselves into an MMO and the relationships we form cemented in a world that isn't real. In the end the only thing that was real are the emotions you felt during the experience. its also worth noting how the game ends. You don't quit MMOs or other community driven games that you play for months/ years after some momentous climax or riveting boss fight. You just kinda... stop playing. There's numerous other parallels in here about getting immersed in the huge forest of a gaming world (instead of quitting, Ned just immerses himself even further, and he doesn't want to be pulled out)

Firewatch is a good game, but not a great game, and not one that I'd recommend at full price.  Let's get started with what the game is not, because I think a lot of people expected based on previews more than what it's offering. It is not really an open world game. Yes, you have access to most of the map at all times, but the objectives are linear and mostly punctuated by taking you back to the tower once you complete them. The world is pretty, but there isn't anything in it. Aside from a few lockboxes you find and objects specifically related to your current objectives, there's nothing you can interact with in the world or see besides trees and ♥♥♥♥.  This game is also not a choice-based story in the vein of Life Is Strange. While you do have dialogue choices, they will not impact any in-game events or the game's ending in any meaningful way. It only affects the dialogue you hear back from your dispatcher.  This game does not have challenges in its gameplay. There are no puzzles, no combat, no way to 'die' or fail your objectives. You are simply going through a story in first person.  While none of these things are by any means requirements for a game to be good, it leaves us only with the story, which unfortunately isn't as good as I had hoped. The idea of the game is that you're alone, and because of your past you're emotionally unstable and susceptible to paranoia, and weird ♥♥♥♥ starts happening that you have to figure out. The game does an amazing job with the setup, and an amazing job of making everything feel creepier and creepier. But the big discovery about what's happening is super disappointing and anticlimactic (though I'll give that it's interesting and unexpected). I think they had a great opportunity to take it a step further and they didn't. And then everything that happens between that and the ending is really dull and unsatisfying.

At its core, Firewatch is a glorified walking simulator. Sure, it doesn't have great mechanics, or Bethesda-worthy plot, but that's alright; that's not why I play walking simulators. Firewatch is exactly what I wanted from it: a beautiful game, with a beautiful setting, soundtrack, and story. I'd caution you from buying this game if you're looking for a Skyrim; but if you're someone who wants to take a 2 or 3 hour break from life and just watch the beauty of nature, this is your game.  In Firewatch, you play as Henry, a new fire lookout in Shoshone National Forest (in Wyoming). You spend your days doing fire lookout stuff, including looking at just how ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful this game is. It kinda makes me want to take a trip to Yellowstone just to take a look with my own eyes. Anyways, along with this, there's a plot (that I won't spoil). It's mediocre, but there are definitely some sad parts, and some happy parts. But, along the way, you'll look at the beauty of the entire map, and listen to great atmospheric soundtracks, and generally have a good time as you explore the forest and everything it has to offer. In addition, character development is pretty nice: I love the personalities in this game, and you really feel like you're Henry and going through the ups and downs of life. Plus, this game isn't mechanically intensive; it's supposed to be a relaxing game, which is great if you're looking to take a break from fast-paced anything.  I have very little criticisms of this game: unlike some other players, I don't really feel duped or anything. I will say that it's a short game (2-3 hours), doesn't have much mechanical or plot depth (counterbalanced by amazing visuals and audio), and the ending is a bit... wonky. Regardless, if you're looking for an awesome experience, I'd definitely recommend Firewatch to you.

Firewatch features excellent adult writing and phenomenal voice acting. It's a story of people experiencing life events beyond their control, and how they deal (or don't deal) with them. Woven around those themes is a compelling mystery story with many twists and reveals. The art style and music are fantastic, complementing the story and furthering a mood.  Some will complain that the game is fairly short and doesn't have a lot of replay potential. Indeed I took my time and finished in about five hours. Compared to $10 for a movie ticket I think it's well worth it, only because the quality of writing and acting here make that a meaningful comparison. The compromise you make for the excellent writing is that the game funnels you into a single storyline despite what appear to be choices along the way. The funneling is subtle and done in a number of ways, and while I knew it was happening it didn't bother me because the writing and presentation work so well. As much as anything this is an interactive movie, or a first-person narrative experience.  If the aim of art is to evoke emotion, Firewatch succeeds brilliantly. Like Red Dead Redemption or The Last of Us, it conveys something more complex than the usual game and likely to stay with me for a long time.

The two major critiques I hear of Firewatch are its almost singular ending and how you can finish it in only a few hours--both of which are missing the point. Firewatch isn't about having a long, extravagent game or an extraordinary, ♥♥♥♥-your-pants ending.  It's about the details, the little nuances in the game you interact with and discover by chance or curiosity. It's about the spectrum of human emotion, trapped in between a gorgeous, surreal environment and a slowly-creeping unease, left only with the voice on a walkie-talkie keeping you company (and possibly a turtle or wooden cutout). It's about how you relate to the characters, and how they relate with you. And for what it's trying to do, Firewatch is just the right length.  The people, the dialogue, the fear and uncertainty and relief--it's just all so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ -real-. That being said, you may need to be in a certain mindset while playing. If you don't have the time to explore the game or aren't in the mood to slow down and snap a couple of photos of the sunset (quite literally), there is no way you can fully enjoy this game right now.   If you liked the Stanley Parable but also like not being trapped in an office hellscape, you're going to love this game. The more you explore, the more of its little secrets are revealed to you as you piece it all together.

Firewatch is a beautiful game with fascinating characters and a very human story. I got it on sale for 13,99€, but in hindsight, it would have been worth full price.   Couple of things to note:  - It seems to be weirdly taxing on the GPU. The fans don't even work this hard with Fallout 4 or a heavily modded Sykrim. I'm not sure if that's specific to my system, or if the requirements just aren't accurate. (R9 390, 4GB)  - Default controls are meh for small hands, change them right at the beginning to your liking to avoid doing it again and again as you keep picking up tools. (Tiny nitpick, but it bugged me until I changed it)  - I saw somewhere that the game was advertised as being six hours long. This may or may not be the case for you, but it heavily depends on how you play. If you stop to explore every clue and listen to every conversation, you can have a six-hour-long relaxed playthrough. If you rush, you can make half that time, perhaps even less. Whether or not that detracts from the experience for you, you'll have to decide for yourself. From my 5.3 hours (as of writing this review), my actual playthrough was about 5 hours, and I usually take my time with these things.   Well, that's it. Great game, would buy again.

Okay, let's just start with the good stuff: The writing and voice acting in this game is absolutely stellar, and I adored the art style. The story was somewhat intriguing at first but it was actually very light, in that I think most of the game shines in the dialogue between you and the woman you're speaking to on the radio. It kept me on edge, though. There were some genuinely tense and suspenseful moments in this game that had me uneasy.  I guess the main reason why I'm let down is that I wish the story was a little less... simple, I guess? Yes, simple stories can be wonderful, but throughout the game I kept expecting that there was more to what was going on, and the theories started swirling around in my head. But I was disappointed that the big 'twist' wasn't really all that big at all, and I just... wasn't that invested in it, to tell you the truth. And the game also isn't as choice-heavy as I was expecting. You don't really get to make any huge decisions, and none of the choices that you do make seemed to matter in the end, and they were just there to mask the game's linearity that lurks underneath.  Another thing I'd hoped was that I wish there was more to DO in the game. The area you get to explore is huge, and it would've been more enjoyable to explore if there'd been actual collectibles or secrets to find. The closest thing to that are the various caches that you stumble upon, but they're all pretty close to the linear path that the story takes you, and are hard to miss. Heck, they all even have the same padlock code. There's not really any replayability with this game, and it's pretty short. Should take you 3 hours or possibly less to complete it if you blitz through it. Took me longer than that cause I tried my best to really look around and get the most out of it, but like I said, there's really not much TO explore.  I don't know if I would recommend this game, I'm sad to say. The good things in it are good, but the lackluster things in it are exactly that as well. Maybe my hopes were too high, I don't know. Overall I was just let down by this game. I understand the kind of narrative experience it was trying to give, but it lacked the extra oomph that a game like, a most recent example would be OXENFREE, had. It left a lot to be desired, and was pretty linear despite its illusion of branching pathways.  I wouldn't stop you if you wanted to experience the game for yourself, but otherwise a playthrough on YouTube would suffice, I think. This game is a 5/10 for me. The art style, voice acting, writing and soundtrack are all great, but everything else sadly doesn't live up to the hype, and I don't think that it's worth the asking price.

The story is amazing, the linear gameplay is fun and the whole game feels like a puzzle only instead it being easy to get into and difficult to master, it's difficult to get into and easy to master. That doesn't mean there is a learning curve; it's completely fair. Your actions actually affect the gameplay which is what made games like Mass Effect great.  And on top of all this, the graphics and voice acting are superb, something that I already expected.  My only complaint is that there are certain technical issues. There isn't a distinct way of telling where an invisible wall is and is not and sometimes they are scattered all over the place. I once tried to get a better view from a cliff (because the views are amazing) so I got up on some rocks. If the new Zelda game, Cuphead, Star Fox Zero, No Man's Sky, Final Fantasy XV and Mighty No. 9 are this good, then 2016 will be a great year for video games. Firewatch gets a 8/10.

I am left with mixed feelings about Firewatch, although those feelings for the most part are positive.  Here are the two greatest negative criticisms—and note that one of them is a spoiler, although I'll do my best to make it relatively generic:  1. The game is short and for the most part, I think, lacks replayability. Playtime clocks in at about 3-4 hours. There may be some possible alternate conversation paths that could be worth playing through to experience but other than that, the main story is wrapped up in a relatively short amount of time for a game currently priced at ~$20.  2. The ending of the game leaves you with a desire for a sense of closure that it doesn't deliver. The primary antagonist escapes, your reasons for beginning the adventure in the first place are left mostly unresolved, and your relationship with the secondary protagonist is left up in the air as well.  Despite all that, I actually got a sense of fulfillment from the game that actually STEMS from its lack of closure. Life simply isn't always as simple and neat as we'd like to be, and the sense of not knowing exactly where to go, or what is going to happen next, echoes perfectly the state that Henry (the main protagonist) must have been left in.  Part of me wants a happy ending for him anyway, and the fact that things are left open lets me write that ending in my head without it being dictated by the game's creators.  Overall this was an enjoyable experience. The game itself is gorgeous, the soundtrack is both peaceful and haunting in equal measures, and the voice acting and characterizations are both believable and touching. I would honestly hesitate to call Firewatch a game; it's more of a playable narrative, an interactive movie that forces you through its sense of isolation and solitude to really connect with the main character.

Firewatch was one of these games where I've visited the store page for the very first time, watched some trailers and ranked the game to number 1 on my wishlist. Literally it was love from the first sight. Short summary of a long text: This game is amazing, it even exceeded my expectations and will maybe forever have a special place in my heart.  People complain about many things: The game is way too short, it is a stupid walking simulator, there is no real open world, dialogues are boring, the story is too linear, the ending is bad. I don't want to argue too much, everybody has his own opinions, I just want to share some of my impressions.   The main reason why Firewatch got my first attention was the graphics. I don't care too much about texture quality, shaders etc. What matters for me is that this game is by far the most beautiful game I've ever played. Firewatch has an awesome graphic style, colors and illuminations create an outstanding atmosphere in a very well designed environment with lots of little details to discover. While it is possible to do this in 3 hours, personally I've never understood why people buy and play games in order to rush through them. This is a wonderful exploration game, so take your time, pace yourself and enjoy. I visited many places, watched the sunset, took many screenshots, looked at the books and information pieces lying around and had fun for around 10 hours. If you have an eye for details 5-6 hours should be viable at least. People are right when they say that Firewatch is some kind of walking simulator with simple interactions. You don't need skill to play this game, there is no challenge, no puzzles, everybody can play through it. And this is great. Because It is so chillfull and allows you to focus on the real package: the nature, your map, your compass, your walkie talkie and you. If you disable the location marker on the map it feels even more realistic. Yes, there are borders limiting your open-world experience, I did not care about, everything else was just so good. Voiceacting is the best I've ever heard in any game, no exaggeration, and the music is also very immersive. Boring small talk? C'mon, this 'boring small talk' is absolutely fantastic and one of the reasons why this game is so authentic and emotional. This is what makes you feel like being a part of the game and not just being the audience of a hollywood blockbuster. It is about small and ordinary things, things we like because we are familiar with them. Do you like french movies? Maybe you know what I mean. While the story builds up tension during progress you should not expect and action-packed survival game, expect heart-touching dialogues and an adult story about people dealing with their feelings and problems instead. Firewatch is unusual mature and honest for a game and for me it did far more than just scratching the surface. I also can't think of a better ending, in my opinion it is perfect because it is refreshing realistic and consistent. Everything is said, there's nothing more to explain.  Seriously, nothing has been really negative for me. Sometimes I've wished there would be a bit less talking, a bit more silence. Also there could be more animals. Often you hear but don't see them, for example at the lake. I have not seen the turtle however, another reason why I need to play the game at least once again. Possibilites for hiding the HUD or crouching for better screenshots would be sweet. Regarding the price it can be reasonable to say that there are cheaper games out there in relation to the pure playtime. But that depends on your viewpoint. For me this gaming experience was really revolutionary and I don't regret a single cent I've spent. Definitely worth my money.  I think there should not be a question if Firewatch is good, because it undoubtedly is, there is just the question if this is a game you would like to play. If you are not totally scared by walking simulators in general and the game appeals to you, you should give Firewatch a go. For me it was certainly one of the best games I've ever played.   Dear developers, thank you so much, you did an awesome job! Days after playing the game, I miss it. And... I miss you Delilah.

I suspect that the negative reviews for this game relate either to its length or its relative simplicity which, while understandable in one sense, is blatantly unfair in another. Firewatch is not a long game, I've beaten it in its entirety, including wandering around a good bit to pick up missed stashes and such (I'd forgotten the combination for the locks at one point) in under 5 hours of play. With that said, I don't feel the slightest qualm about having paid $20 for the priveledge of venturing through this masterpiece.  It is best advised that you approach Firewatch not as a game, which it is in only the most technical of senses, but instead as an interactive movie. The vast majority of choices you make in the game will have only the most minor of effects on the story, and many don't have a meaningful outcome at all, and that's okay. Firewatch is immersive in a way that few other titles are, In many games, you are empowered to shape the main character into anything you like or not at all, but not in Firewatch, In a bit of masterful design you are not left without choice, which would have served to detach you from the story as a mere observer, but instead provided just a bit of choice, the exact right amount to give you investment with the character and his story without requiring a vastly branching story tree to accomodate each choice and its' outcome.  This sense of investment, coupled with the beautiful artstyle creates an experience like none other. It pairs the best features of video games and movies to create a triple-feature-length tale that draws you in and leaves you wanting more. Henry is (most likely) not you, his story is not yours, but because of the small choices you are allowed to make along the line you are emotionally invested in his story and that is what makes Firewatch so brilliant. You are left hanging on the edge of your seat as the mystery unfolds and wrapped up in the tale on through its inevitable conclusion. I paid full price for this game I would be glad to hand Campo Santo another $20 and another $20 and another $20 for future stories like this one. Compared to going out to a movie, for example, there is no competition, Firewatch wins hands-down and, even better, it's cheaper by far if you factor in concessions. You won't get a thousand hours of gameplay out of Firewatch, and its replay value is limited for the most part, but if you treat it as an interactive story, not a game, you won't be disappointed.
Imagine what a combination of the exploration of Kholat, the mystery of Gone Home and the esthetics of Team Fortress 2 would result in.  Yup, that's pretty close to Firewatch!

Firewatch is a beautiful single player mystery game, set in a Wyoming national park in 1989. You play as Henry, a man who has taken a job in isolation in order to escape the reality of his life. We learn at the start that his wife suffers from alzheimers and no longer recognizes him, and so he deals with the guilt of putting her into a home by becoming a lookout in the Wyoming wilderness.  The only human contact Henry has is with Delilah, his supervisor who keeps him company via radio and sends him out to deal with potential fire risks, check communication lines and other such duties. The story takes an adrenaline-pumping turn when a set of strange circumstances arise. The teenage girls he tells off for lighting fireworks are reported missing a week later, and someone appears to be keeping him under surveillance.  I want to keep this review spoiler free so I won't reveal any more of what happens, but as the mystery deepens and Henry's relationship with Delilah comes into question, the already immersive story of Firewatch continues to drive the player forward with an urgency that has you gasping for breath come the end.  Being a first-person game that could almost be considered to be a walking exploration simulator, it's important to note the key elements at play here that absolutely make the game a worthy experience: the delicious, sun-drenched environments, the perfect voice acting for Henry and Delilah and a story that moves at a fast pace while keeping you wanting more.  As the mystery of Firewatch unfolded during my 4 and a half hour playthrough, I found myself questioning everything, coming up with crazy theories as I worked towards figuring out what was going on, and so it was that I found the actual ending to be something of a let down. It felt like the game had been building up to this amazing climax only for it to fizzle just a little bit right when it mattered the most.  With that said, it was a thoroughly enjoyable journey. I would absolutely play this game again even though I know what happens and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who values beautiful landscapes, well written characters and immersive storytelling.

All this said, I cannot ignore that this story had lots of potential that was simply never tapped. It seems as if they had a vision of where the game would go and then all of a sudden the gave it up. There is a beautiful setup for something strange and unbelievable and all they manage to pull off is 'surprising.'   In short, I would play this game. Its worth it. Never (except perhaps for times when I was sure there was going to be a jump scare) did I consider my experience un-enjoyable. However, if you are expecting a storytelling masterpiece I would set your expectations strait (and leave room to be surprised if you enjoy it more than I did!). It's hard to make a game that contains a real story, and they achieved that at least. We need more games like this.

I want to like this game. I really do. I think Firewatch is really trying to do something that is very rare in games, and that's exploring a very complicated relationship. In Firewatch, that relationship is between Hank, who is married to his wife who has early onset dementia, and Delilah, his boss that he only communicates through the radio.  The game gives you various things to say to Delilah with prompts from items, settings, and responses when she contacts you. It's up to you to choose what to say, and a lot of options are to flirt with Delilah.   All of this is fine, and it's hard to say anything about this game without spoiling it, so I'll tread lightly here. There's a big tonal shift in the game about halfway through, and I was honestly surprised by it. The game started referencing characters that were only mentioned in passing, and now suddenly they were a big part of the story. It left me scratching my head, wondering if I was just not paying enough attention.   Look, I don't really know what else to say about the story, but I will say that it just left me extremely underwhelmed and slightly confused. The game is executed well; the voice acting is some of the best I've heard in gaming, it's really stunning to look at, and it really is fun to explore the Wyoming wilderness as a Firewatch person-guy. But in the end, I think it dropped the ball.   I don't want you to not play this game because of my review, because I think a lot of people will find enjoyment from this game. I don't think any of my problems that I have with it are especially damning. It's not like the game doesn't work, or isn't fun or whatever. It's just that I don't think it succeeds in what it specifically sets out to do, and I think that's why I'm not recommending it.

Firewatch showcases some of the best possible facets of storytelling, allowing you to fully comprehend, interpret and forge the backstory for that character, and how they respond to scenarios and people. Many complaints about this game are due to the length of it compared to the price, and at $20, that's understandable, but when compared to a film at ~$15, this experience is far more fleshed out and comprehensive, displaying such a beautiful understanding of storytelling and intrigue that other games actively disappoint me at their lack of attempting to expend that much effort.   The aesthetic of the game allows for even the most mundane of sights to be wonderful experiences, with many humerous and interesting things hidden throughout the rather large and fluid map. For a 'Walking Simulator' the game teaches you alot of mechanics, and uses the radio and your own observation as a genius supplement for a tutorial, as it revels in you finding new things to talk to Delilah about, with some of even the most minute details being well fleshed-out discussions that tell you more about not only your only companion, but yourself.  All these thoughts of pseudo-isolation are aided by the fact that you never actually SEE anybody else until very abruptly at the finale, allowing for an incredible amount of tension to be built during the mid to late area of the story, in which a mystery presents itself and is constantly elaborated upon, and evokes feelings that I personally have not felt since Lost, with the sensation of discovery being the most satisfied I've felt in a huge amount of time.  The music is the as the one that composed the music from Gone Home, which shows not only in the music, but the setting, as they are both set within the same time period and deal with the same themes of isolation and pseudo-horror. But, anyways, the music is incredible with a country-esque theme to it, being mixed with the 70s-80s synth, allowing for an incredible range to be achieved and atmosphere to not only be built, but amplified.  Another thing about this game that has brought a large amount of flak to it is the ending, being criticised as too sudden and not closing every topic brought up, when for me, (Though most certainly not for all) it closes itself just as it started, by using you, it has you think about all of the possibilites and results of the ending via providing no definitive one, hell, if you want to, you can even refuse the ending and allow it to resolve in one singular way, via doing nothing.  And to revisit the earlier topics in a TL;DR format, the Art Style is outright beautiful, with an incredible amount of thought being poured into it, the story is one of 3 that have permanently stuck with me (The others being Bastion and Transistor) due to just how well and intelligently made it was, and this game even excels in the area of game design itself, even though, due to the medium of the game being a 'Walking Simulator' isn't even close to being held back.  All in all, I would recommend buying this game, downloading, turning your internet and lights off, and then taking a few hours to allow this game to dazzle you. Many people pose the question, 'What is this game life?' and the answer is very simple. The game is akin to the Text-Based Adventure games from the 1970's and 80's, where you explore your environment, solve simplistic puzzles and experience a story heavy experience. Text-Based Adventure Games have been coined as Interactive Fiction and that really is what Firewatch is. You explore a vibrant and colorful world, uncovering a mystery while interacting with another watchperson via a walkie-talkie. The most important thing you need to know is if the story is good and if the characters are engaging. The answer to those questions is yes. The story is engaging. I have heard critics say that the story has a lackluster ending and I disagree. There are themes and elements that leave the ending open to your interpretation and that always sparks controvery. The reality is that the game is a delightful mixture of emotions that tug on the heartstrings in a variety of ways. If you are looking for a story-driven interactive fiction, then the game is for you. It isn't for everyone, I understand that, but for those looking for this style of game, it will not disappoint.

It captivates you, makes you tear up over your sick wife, makes you feel all sorts of feels then ends, leaving you confused and hungry for more.  The game might be short, the dialogue choices might not make a huge difference to the linearity of the story, but Firewatch is one of the best Single-Player experiences I've had in a game for a long time.   9.5/10

I disliked Firewatch and was surprised how disappointing the story was. I knew it was a mystery and not a game, but I refunded it on the basis of it being a disappointment solely on its merits as a storytelling piece. The story was so uninteresting to me that I'm confused that others would be captivated by it or find the dialogue compelling in such a setting.  As a firewatch in a Wyoming forest, I would expect to feel a sense of responsibility for the safety of others first, and a sense of adventure second. But I found neither in Firewatch. I felt little sense of adventure going through points on a map at the command of my supervisor. And I felt no responsibility: the story puts me in charge of a character who took a firewatch job without any interest in it or qualifications, just to escape from the harsh problems of reality. Not shoes I would want to fill. Worse, I'm expected to believe my character's supervisor would immediately shirk her responsibility in a life-or-death situation just to avoid talking to authorities, and that my character would be okay with that and continue to converse with her in a friendly or even romantic way.  The conversations and connection between the player's character and his supervisor play no role in the mystery except to present conspiracies that you know won't play out.  The introductory videos on Steam try to build up suspense, drama and humor that don't really exist in the game. I believed the story was going to pick up as certain factors were presented, and that my character was going to learn to deal with the conflict or have to figure his way out of something. But in fact as the mystery 'unravels' I found my character was all along having a sort of pointless non-encounter with someone I knew nothing about and cared nothing about. So there was no arc. Then the story ended even less dramatically, punctuating the weakness of the main discovery with nothing at all happening with another character I cared nothing about.  The graphics and audio were great, especially for an indie title, but I did not buy the game for graphics and audio.  I see a missed potential. I may have enjoyed the interactions if this had gameplay rather than just storytelling, and I had been given some challenges performing duties as a firewatch with some risk and reward. With the environment that Firewatch has (minus the invisible collision meshes that prevent scaling over anything 10 inches tall), I might find some enjoyment discovering and locating fires, calling them in, and even fighting the flames as the story unfolds. But Firewatch is not intended to be a game at all, and the story failed me on its own.  A couple of other notes: (1) I considered the walkthrough format, being commanded to go from point A to point B to point C in the order prescribed by the storytelling, to be an abuse of my time in this context; (2) any indie can do better than a 55 degree FOV that can only be changed by a registry hack; (3) when changing controls, a previously mapped control should be removed when a new mapping is made, rather than preventing a new mapping, and Firewatch not only prevents the mapping, but apparently has no way to remove a control mapping, which is a disaster.  1 / 10 - Story 6 / 10 - Interface 8 / 10 - Audio/Music/Voices 9 / 10 - Graphics  A mystery is nothing without its story, so overall 1 / 10.  Steam refund process 10 / 10.
