Firewatch is a beautiful and gripping experience. It's smartly written, with well developed characters and some of the best dialogue and voice acting I've came across in any game.  It mixes genre well, with genuinely moving moments and characters you're drawn to invest in, while keeping you consistency gripped with incredibly tense thrilleresque sections. The vast and stunning natural environment around you contributes to a feeling of eerie isolation as the game goes on, and you share your characters increasing anxiousness and paranoia when it becomes apparent that you are not alone.   Firewatch's other great success is how this all draws you to invest completely in the central mystery; and ultimately this is also where the game disappointingly falls a little flat.. From the moving and poignant introduction, through the consistent building of tension, and suspense at the unravelling of the games main mysteries, to an urgent ending as the forest fires rage and close in around you.. there comes a suspenseful expectation which is not met by the far more understated (both in tone and event) and somewhat anticlimactic ending. While in some ways I do actually like the ending in terms of those characters and the games themes, due to the build-up it inevitably makes the experience feel a little confused in tone in the end, and just a little unfulfilling.  On the whole I really enjoyed Firewatch. Recommended.

One of my most anticipated releases of 2016, and sadly I bet it'll end up as one of my biggest disappointments.   Firewatch focuses on a very grounded and human story, about a man named Henry who's just trying to get away from life and get some perspective on things. As the story develops you as the player get to choose what kind of man you want him to be, through the conversations you have with your watch partner Delilah. This is where the game shines the brightest and it was pretty much the only thing keeping me interested throughout the game. The dialog is well thought out with great voice acting to boot. There were moments I found myself grinning like a complete idiot because of the friendly banter between the characters, and there were also the heavier darker moments which made me genuinely feel for them as well. Add to this a beautiful woodland setting and a great soundtrack and you've got yourself one heck of an immersive experience.  This is pretty much the only good I have to say about this game though, sadly. When it comes to mechanics it falls short in pretty much every department. The hiking around is teadious and I found myself having to bring up my map way more often than I'd like just to see that I hadn't gotten turned around. And while we're on the subject, there really isn't any point to exploring becuase most of the areas are locked away until the game tells you it's ok to progress down the storyline. Most of the areas you explore are just big empty spaces anyway (albeit pretty spaces, but vast and devoid of content nonetheless), so in the end I just found myself plowing through the story just so I could get to the next section of dialog.  And to adress the elephant in the room: this game is short. As you can tell by my game time I beat it in two sittings at around the 4 hour mark. For a 17 pound game this is not ok, no matter how great your characters are.  At the end of the day though, I advice you to get this game, just not at full price. And I genuinely wish the devs the best of luck. Its been a long time since I felt so invested in the relationship between two videogame characters and I'm eager to see what Campo Santo can cook up in the future.

Firewatch is an intersting game that a lot of people have some beef with. So let's get the cons out of the way. The game is worth $20 and for its length it's a fair bit overpriced. However, if you look at it like it's a 3-4 hour movie you play then it's two 10 dollar movie tickets. Not exactly being gyped but still kinda short. The other thing people can be sour about is the ending. There are no real spoilers here but to say the least it ends a little abruptly. But the old adage rings true here: It's not the destination, it's the journey.   Now the messy part is over, I can drool over the game with all its good things. First, the writing. It's a mystery game, so it's the most important genre to keep interesting and the viewer engaged. They do a very good job with Firewatch. It's a slow burning tale of two people figuring out what's going on that isn't quite normal. The characters are expertly written by the two writers for Telltale's The Walking Dead and so the two main characters have a naturally interesting relationship throughout the game. As a normal man doing a normal job, the introduction of the mystery into this normal enviroment keeps people intrigued enough to explore the story. As well as the story, players will like the slice of Wyoming wilderness that you are stationed in. It's large enough to make each place feel different enough, but small enough so that each place is familiar enough to you as you play. Firewatch is so chock full of things from its world that it feels like a real place. Every lake and forest has its own name, there's a mascot akin to Smokey the Bear, and it's more real that it's based in a real place. Small elements in a story like this makes it on par with Alan Wake and even Dark Souls for setting a tone for it's lore.  TL;DR: It's a fairly short game but extremely dense with a good mystery and characters, and a real world waiting to be explored.

Reality after finishing the game is different...  + *Great voice acting and dialogues *Story *Graphic stylization *Environment of Wyoming forest   - *Short. And I mean short, 3-4hrs for first gameplay is more than disapointing. I am one of people who dont have countles free hours to play games, but I would expect double play time. *Performance issues even on higher spec. computers (could be fixed hopefully if devs will look on it) *Tunnel game. I was really expecting that it will be open world.. but you have only few paths where you can go and it is ridiculous that your character can not even climb small rock or go through bush... *Decisions dont change the game. You get different conversation options, but result will be the same..   Neutral: *Price. I dont have problem to pay more money for quality game, but in this case 20Euro for 3hr game with issues above is too much. But it's dev's decision and they can put any price they want.. *Forest is empty. You see one deer at beginning and thats it. I would expect to see some animals sometimes, but nothing.. there are some birds far far away on sky... *Game was presented as mysterious, dark, scary... dead teens, somebody watching you, vandalized outlook etc. Reality is different, but I dont want to spoil here.  Well, too bad that you can not give 'neutral' review, but it has to be Yes or No. As mentioned by some people, if this was Episode 1 from the whole game I would highly recommend it although it has some issues. But as a full final game, I am still saying yes go for it, but in case there will be at least 50% discount.  Right now I am giving 6/10. If they fix performance issues it will go to 7/10. In case they will release some additional content (preferably for free) it could go higher.  Sorry devs, it could be really really good game.

Great dialogue, excellent voice performances, a minimal soundtrack, and some beautiful visuals brought real life to this first-person adventure game. Firewatch is the type of game that I really enjoy playing, and although the game is fairly linear, i think that this is a game that works with how linear it is. The best thing about this game is its atmosphere and relationship you develope with the 'person on the other end of a handheld radio'. The gripes i had with this game are severely outweighed by the things that kept me interested in it and although it was a mere 3 and a half hours of gametime, it was well worth the sale price of $9.99. Definetly a game I feel that most everyone should expirience, wether that is playing or watching someone play it. Probably bound to wind up one of my favorite games of the year, but that certainly is not going to be true for everybody. It's not as thematically interesting as Stanley Parable or The Beginner's Guide, and not as visually interesting as something like Dear Esther, but instead goes for something more comparable to Gone Home. Even as somebody that actually kinda liked Gone Home, however, I am very confindent in saying that Firewatch is leaps and bounds better.   Voice acting is top notch and that alone sold me on the game. The mystery isn't nessisarily the best concieved one but it was more than engaging enough to keep me engaged through the 4 hour run time, and it serves as more of a vehicle to get to know the characters. It's also rather plesant to look at, which is nice considering a lot of the time spent will be wondering around the wilderness.  The gameplay is bound to get on a lot of people's nerves. Yes, it's pretty much just walking around, and yes, sometimes the distances they make you travel between locations of interest are somewhat arbitrary, but I found that it helped me get lost in the world more easily, and by the end of it I knew the trails a lot better than I expected I would. The total playtime is also going to turn off a lot of people, but I was never really bothered by shorter games. In some aspects it helps this game, even, as it never outstays it's welcome. If you want a long game for $20 stay away, though.  I was anticipating this game greatly ever since I first saw footage of it, and I was not at all let down by it. It's emotional and interesting and maybe even a little shocking if you're willing to lose yourself in it, although I admit that a lot of people will probably figure out what's going on before the game reveals it fully. I'm not as fond of it as I am The Beginner's Guide but it's still probably up there as far as 'walking simulators' go. If you hate these kinds of games already there's pretty much no way this one will change your mind.

The replayability is ofcourse very low, once you played through it, unless you just want to experience it once again.

I have never written a review for a game on steam before. I finished this game two hours ago and I feel a true sense of loss that I'm no longer captivated in its world. The theatrical rollercoaster grabs you right from the start. Heartstrings are pulled as you make choices about the hero's backstory, binding you to his character emotionally...and then you pick up that radio... The voice acting of the two lead characters is excellent, their chemistry is palpable. The visuals are completly immersive, you can almost smell the woodsmoke from fires and feel the crunch of dry pine needles under your feet. There have been a number of complaints about the ending; that it feels anticlimactic. Let yourself break through that gamer barrier that needs the adrenaline pumping, all encompassing finale. The story remains true to itself. if you are a romantic soul and a humanist you will see that the value of the ending lies in its realisim. The character's frustrations and disappointments are spellbindingly relatable.

I cannot recommend this simply because as a complete package, this 'game' is a disappointment.   First, the positive: this game looks good and runs smooth. I never had any glitch or hiccup. There aren't any real video options to play around with but the game booted up fine, ran at 1080 and maintained a consistent framerate. The voice acting was pretty good and very realistic.   Now the bad: this game is just a major disappointment. The plot starts off suspenseful and you are left wondering how things will play out and what impact your decisions will have. It kinda draws you in because you want to find out what will happen next. Things take a turn for the worse, however, when you begin to realize that the story isn't really that good. And all that suspense you thought would keep you going through the game kinda just wimpers away. Also, the end game was spectacularly bland.   When I finished the game at about 4 hours, I realized that this really wasn't a game at all. It was just a story. A bad one at that. Dialogue options don't change things much and everything ends the same.   The game really loses the little charm it had at the beginning when you start to run into invisible walls and stop following the game's structured sequences without any repercussion or consequence. Also, you can't die. Where's the fun in that?  I think video game news outlets should really stop hyping these types of games. I bought into this hype only to regret this purchase. I can't understand how video game journalists can praise a game that you can literally watch on youtube and have the same exact experience.

Everything from the sounds to the visuals of the game, I absolutely love it. The atmosphere was spot on, the sense of solitude(which I love), it is done right. Also, the music helps elevate the tone and feel of the game. Also the the feel and sound of wind blowing, it's perfect, I love it.  The conversations between Henry and Delilah was really authentic. From the moment they first met to the end, you can here the tone of the conversation changes as they bond throughtout the game, it felt natural. All the characters including Ned have their own past that they're trying to forget and avoid but the reality is, that it'll catch up to them in time and they would have to face it eventually. Rich Sommer and Cissy Jones really did an amazing voiceover work in this game.  I was really into the story/mystery part of the game. It kept me engaged throughout my gameplay of it. Which not all video game nowadays does it for me, and I appreciate this so much.  Yes, can't deny that there's a lot of walking in the game. It's not an open world as you would like it to be sometimes. There's definitely exploration you can do by yourself in your time without the game forcing you to progress forward. Sometimes I just feel like they cut some of the dialogue out or change the story of the game throughout the development process.  Like most people, I really do wish it was longer. After finished with the game, it left me wanting more of it. I want more Henry, more Delilah, more Firewatch. With only few people working on this game, I'd say Campo Santo really did an excellent work on this as their debut title. Overall, it was an amazing experience and I enjoy every second of it. I really do love the atmosphere and the sense of solitude being in the woods and mountains. Really looking forward to see what's their next project going to be. Congrats!

If you've played 'Gone Home' before then you will be familiar with the style of gameplay that Firewatch has to offer. You'll get a sense of where the story is heading within the opening 10 minutes, but it's then up to you to do the rest! You only get out of the story what you put into it, so if you just wish to coast through the game don't expect to get too attached to either the story or the characters. In contrast the more you explore the National Forest an interact with the wilderness around you the more story you uncover and better understand the characters. Despite the strong story however it is a little on the short side. You could probably blast through the game in little under 4 hours if you put your mind to it. Considering this is the first game by the developer it's well worth playing if you have a passion for narrative based gameplay :)

I have mixed feelings about Firewatch, and ultimately can't recommend it. It will appeal to a specific audience, but most may want to give it a pass. Don't go in expecting a traditional survival/horror game, and instead anticipate beautiful scenery, witty dialogue, interesting characters and an overall enjoyable 3.5 - 5 hours. I'm glad I played it, but am a bit disappointed I had to pay $20 for the experience.   SPOILERS BELOW  The game suffers significantly in its final act; it ultimately felt as if the creators had too many balls in the air and dropped 90% of them. That said, some of what they achieved and their unique take on the genre is definitely worth a play-through. The design is beautifully done, evoking a sense of paranoia and slipping sanity that hinges on the unreliable narrator. You can't trust yourself, and that's really interestingly done here.  Was it a let down? Yeah. I'm not sure what I wanted to happen but I know I wanted it to have more meaning, more impact, something. I want to know what the burned down cabin was, why there were bears, why would he have faked an entire research site? Ned's actions don't make sense within the story, and it's waved away with the explanation of PTSD. I wanted to meet Delilah, to know more about my wife, to run across other people or have a chance to explore different cave systems. I think a collectible system would have improved the game significantly- a reason to explore the wilderness would have been fantastic, and could have fleshed out the bare bones world. The game has the illusion of choice, but very little reason to venture off the strictly set path.   There may be some value in a replay- different choices, different dialogue options- but without significant reworking or the release of new content, the ending would feel the same way. I wish this game had lived up to its promise.

Campo Santos could definitely have done more with the title, taking different directions, added alternate outcomes. There is an option to turn off the map indicator for Henry which would leave you only able to know where you are based on natural landmarks. A great game all in all.

Firewatch is not a game with great gameplay. It is not a long game with endless possibilites and replay value. Firewatch is a game that wants you to sit down and enjoy a story. You can interact with and change that story, but it's just that - a really good story. Firewatch will make you think in ways you wouldn't expect to and feel ways you don't necessarily want to.  Many people claim that the ending was so bad that it ruined the experience. Maybe it's because I walked in expecting the ending to be abysmal, but it's really not all that bad. I'll admit - it could have been better. It ends on an ambiguous note, and doesn't really explain itself fully, but that is no strike against it. The same could be said of American Psycho, Inception, The Thing, and 2001: A Space Odyssey, but they're all still great films.  Firewatch will be added to the list of infamous 'non-games': The Stanley Parable, The Beginner's Guide, The Novelist, The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, and Gone Home, to name a few. These are games which have no interest in giving good gameplay, but deliver a story that leaves you thinking for a few days. If you enjoyed Firewatch, I recommend giving all of those a try.  TL;DR Firewatch is a game with nothing to offer but a nice graphical style and a fantastic story. Do not expect a fantastic ending that wraps up everything perfectly in a box for you. It is great.

*An explanation of the ending without spoilers.*  Now I’m not one to usually write a review about one, but seeing how this game has gotten so much hate because many felt as though the ending was abrupt or lazy. In the next paragraph I hope to explain that in my opinion of why people disliked the ending, and how that resulted in so much hate towards the game.  I want to first start off saying that it can’t be denied that the developers at Campo Santo made a beautiful game which you can’t deny even if you think the ending sucked for Firewatch. Now onto why I think many people thought the ending sucked. From the first day Henry showed up at the Shoshone National Forest in the Wyoming wilderness for the firewatcher job, he was asked an bizarre question by his supervisor Delilah, which was “What are you escaping from”. Now to keep it spoil free I won’t mention why, but through the next day’s Henry will start to get more bizarre questions that he will both ask himself and Delilah. Now throughout the game there starts to become this one big problem that Henry and Delilah are trying to solve, this problem has you guessing, and questioning so much. This problem is what I think was the cause to many hating the ending, because throughout the game the as you’re getting closer to solving this problem, the rising action increases ever more, until you reach the climax, which is the answer to that problem. Now during that rising action there becomes many speculations on what this problem is which leads to the player overthinking it and becoming frustrated when it wasn’t what they hoped it would be. The same can be said about the ending where things didn’t go the way players wanted it to go, but to think that certain events would play out in the way you hoped were not possible. Because if you remember what I mentioned about day one, that this place was an escape for Henry, that he was carrying weight from his place back home, and that while he was here in Shoshone National Forest he could feel free, but once he leaves he has to return to the world he once left. Now some of this might not make sense since you haven’t played it, but I’m telling it this way so I don’t spoil it for you.  Now I hope I was able to convince you that Firewatch is a great game, that should not be rejected because some players felt it didn’t go the way they wanted to and that Campo Santo has given us a masterpiece for only a mere $20, while many AAA developers out there charge us $60 for something they can’t even deliver on now a days.

Some videogames have a great storyline. Some of them do a good narrative job.  But Firewatch is a great story that  also  happens to be a videogame. The storytelling is so mature and compelling that I can say I've never experienced anything like this game before. It's been weeks since I've finished it and I still think about it - like a great book, or a great movie, it keeps on living in my imagination.  A great story doesn't have to be complex, and this is a good example. As a Park Ranger, you move in for a quiet summer in harmony with nature. The only nuisance could be your supervisor that you regularly get over the radio but what could go bad? Worst case scenario, a fire starts and you'll have to call for help and let the pros do their job. But more is to come...  One of the best things about Firewatch is that it is relatively short. Making it longer wouldn't have made any sense and would have broken the magic of walking around the beautiful map of Firewatch. It's simple but realistic. The athmosphere is near perfect, subtle and smart. This game isn't about quantity anyway, it's about quality.  Wonderful game. If only they were more like this.

This is my first ever review on Steam, but I felt like I had to support this brilliant game. I have played a number of 'walking simulator' games and this is the first one that clicked with me. The characters, setting, story, voice acting, and emotional weight are all perfectly done. Without going into specifics, I was nearly brought to tears at least three times during my playthrough. This is a game by adults, for adults that left me thinking about characters and conversations days after playing.

The first few minutes of the game have you making distinct choices, leading you to believe that this is a game that adapts to your decisions. It's not. You are simply walking from plot point A to plot point B. It's as linear as linear gets. They seem to have forgotten to include 'gameplay' in this game.

Absolutely nothing happens, there is nothing to explore, there is nothing to DO other than hold W to the next waypoint then click on something. There is a very thin illusion of choice and the third act is definition of anti-climactic. Pretty game, not even worth close to $15, I did not rush through this and I finished it in about 3.5 hours, I did feel some tension, but it was all for nothing. The story is completely unresolved and really fell apart towards the end. I'm sure this game will get tons of glowing reviews for being 'different', when really, it was just a boring game with good marketing and voice acting.

It seems there is much commentary about whether Firewatch lives up to the 'hype' that it has been getting lately. Personally I originally thought it was another run of the mill wilderness exploration game. Oh boy, was I wrong. Gameplay- This game is classified as a 'walking simulator,' but it really doesn't feel like it due to always being able to talk about things to delilah. FireWatch really is an interactive story. Everything about this game is beautifully written and it is very grounded in a realistic story. It should be noted that you actually have to explore and look around to get everything despite it being a relatively linear game, which in my opinion, helps naturally pad out the game. I played it with a friend and it made the game a lot more interesting with two different people making decisions and thinking of new theories as the game runs its course. A lot of negative reviews think all the tension is dropped at the end and this is true but thats what the game is trying to do. A theme of the game is the characters oer analyzing things as more of the plot is revieled and more questions arrive. The payoff is meant to be a little less then what you expected because you are listening to these people who are on edge and paranoid, making up outlandish theories. The game is doing its job because you begin to believe in these theories and believe in Henry and Delilah. As for the ending, its easy to see that Delilah is selfish simply from details in game besides it flat-out telling you at one point. So her actions at the end aren't really deviating from her character at all. Although im sure people wanted this game to end happily with the love story being all tied up it just wasn't what the story was meant to be. I like the game more because of this, it feels very human and maybe even close to home for some others because of its lack of closure. Can't wait for a book or a sequel.... ;P

Was it done deliberately to indicate that the game contains a deeper riddle to be solved, touching on the nature of the human condition? OR did a character place it there carelessly, just like you, I and everyone else does. Look at your shelf; is everything arranged carefully and in the same direction? Or like me, does your bookshelf have a pile of Robert Jordan paperbacks stacked haphazardly between your neatly arranged ADnD modules and your books for homebrewing and mushroom hunting?  This is a game that explores a very emotional and traumatic time in a person's life. I'm going to guess that it's easier to get sucked into this if you're married and/or have kids but that is NOT a prerequisite. It is a game about coping with loss (or NOT coping, if that's how you decide to play it), paranoia, investigation, being able to just enjoy something pretty and handling your emotions. Not gonna lie, there were some moments where my computer room becamse surprisingly dusty. There are also some legitimately scary moments in this game that gave me worse feelings of unease and fright than your typical horror game does. I mean, seriously, is anyone still scared of zombies or otherworldly possessions from space? You know what did scare me? Raccoon Carter. But you know what scared me worse? Finding an abandoned kid's backpack.  ... I just... Look, there are lots of reasons to buy this game but only one not to; if you're looking to shoot the bad guys and jump from a burning building onto a plane which is going to crash moments later, go play Uncharted, I think I saw it on sale. If you're open to a game which plays on much more realistic fears and aren't looking for a bit of escapism, buy this game. If you want charcters you can actually relate to, buy this game. Buy this game because everyone either was, or knows a kid who was too nerdy for his own good but couldn't be anything else. Buy this game if you want to explore what happens when an otherwise perfect life gets dealt a blow it can't seem to recover from.

I rate the game Firewatch 4/5. Good, but not a masterpiece.  This is a good first person perspective suspense-thriller personal drama story. Though very linear and relatively short, this was still interesting and humorous enough that I played it through 3 times (mostly to ascertain how much (or how little) freedom this game actually gives you). Ultimately, Firewatch is more of a mildly interactive story than an actual game. Indeed, there are places in the story where this 'game' almost seems to play itself out and there are no choices you can make which have any great, ultimate effect on what happens in this game or on how it ends. You, the player, are essentially just along for the ride. It's an interesting (and at times, extremely tense) ride though.  The good: +Good Graphics throughout, especially outdoors (which is where most of this game takes place. This game has a nice, well thought out cartoony, graphic novel style. One may think this graphical style would be enough to keep the game feeling humorous throughout but surprisingly this game depicts some increasingly tense and suspenseful situations. There are wonderful graphical flourishes throughout and a great attention to detail. Also, when you look down you can see your character's body, unlike many other games. Your character's hands do look a bit too pudgy and odd though.  +Great sound. Perhaps perfect sound actually. The sounds are realistic and excellently detailed. Crickets chirp and birds sing and bushes rattle mysteriously while strange metallic tinkling can barely be heard in the exact places where you should hear it. Every sound is meaningful and intentional. The sounds are vitally important to creating the tense atmosphere of this game and succeed brilliantly. The music works well to increase tension even further but wouldn't make a great soundtrack in itself. Voice acting is outstanding throughout and the script writing is excellent as well with many witty exchanges and jokes.  +The game controls well (it feels like you are playing as an out-of-shape but muscular guy which is exactly what your character is) and the controls mapped very well (and very easily) to my keyboard and mouse using the control settings menu. The controls are also fairly simple making this an ideal game to use if you want to learn how to play a first person perspective game and are uncertain as to how such game's should be controlled or are not yet very good at it. It is a bit odd though that you can make your out-of-shape character sprint around (including up hills) as much as you want to. It was also a bit overly difficult to figure out how to operate the radio and select dialogue choices (Odd considering what a vitally important element of gameplay this is) but I got used to it.  +The environment is big but not so big that things get boring if you enjoy being in the real-life great outdoors. It is big enough to get lost in but small enough that you can easily find your way back again. The environment feels like a fairly realistic outdoor area as well (especially if you were in some sort of state park). It is a bit grandiose for a mere national forest but that's a minor issue which is easy to overlook.  The Mediocre: +/-This game could have had better pacing. I sometimes felt as though the game was trying to hurry me along through its plot. I particularly wanted there to be more peaceful moments wherein I was not encouraged to hurry but instead encouraged to explore for the sake of exploring. There's lots to see and have your character respond over the radio about but mostly you are busy with some more pressing matter (like trying to make sure someone doesn't set the forest on fire). There's no actual time limit on completing objectives (perhaps there should have been though) but wandering idly along looking at every little thing that catches your interest while someone or other is setting off fireworks in a high-danger fire area seems really strange, particularly after your boss has just told you to hurry (but doing just that kind of thing what you must do in order to get the most character and plot development out of the dialogue in this game's story. The game does give you an opportunity to go exploring on your own before the plot fully winds up but it doesn't seem like its encouraging you to do so at that point.  The Bad: -It's almost impossible to figure out just how nasty or sarcastic your character is going to be before you select a dialogue choice (if I wanted the character to say anything at all). This encouraged me to want to play through the game again and again in a very frustrating way because, after the game was done the first time, I had yet to really see what would happen if I had responded in a way I wanted to. I had responded to several plot-critical situations with sarcasm or with nasty remarks wholly on ACCIDENT because the game won't tell you whether you are about to say something sarcastic or nasty. It only gives you the first few words of what you might say and nothing more. It's hard to choose one dialogue option over another based just off of that. All Dialogue options should have been labeled with easy to understand emotional labels such as 'sarcasm' or 'angry' or 'depressed' and so forth to give the player a heads-up on what they are about to make the character say before they let the character say it. The dialogue systems in Deus Ex: Human Revolution and in Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 3 are head and shoulders above the one which this game is built around.  -Regardless of what you say or don't say and regardless of whether you have your character respond at all (even to direct questions being repeatedly screamed at you), the same basic plot occurs and the same basic situations happen each time you play. This game is very linear and (sometimes as sheer luck would apparently have it) nothing you say or do really makes much permanent difference to how the plot develops. This is totally unrealistic. If I refuse to talk to anyone at all, there will be ramifications. If I act insulting on a constant basis, other ramifications will ensue. But in Firewatch? The same thing happens each time. Some of the same dialogue will be spoken NO MATTER WHAT YOU SAY OR DO. Your relationship with the main character will seem different to you but that does not change whether or not the forest burns down and nothing you say or do can change whether or not you prevent it. After playing the game 3 times in a row this inability to affect the game world in any meaningful way left me with a feeling of mild frustration. This game should have been more like a choose-your-own adventure story with multiple different endings. Instead it's like a normal suspense-thriller novel. It's fun the first one or two times but it wears thin far too quickly.   -I could more easily accept the fact that this is a relatively short game if it had a plethora of potential endings but it doesn't. It has just two endings and they both seem a bit anti-climactic.Despite it's flaws though, I'm still glad I played it once, twice, even thrice (to see and hear everything the game has go offer) but I will not play it a fourth time. Now that I really have seen 90% of what this game has to offer, playing it yet again would just be repetitious and boring.

This is a good game. Ok, it more of a interactive movie sort of game but it's still a game.   Some say it's a game of unused opportunities and they are right. This game should have been at least 15-20 hours long yet we got only about 5 hours. Granted you never used sprint button, a feature literally made to make you finish the game faster. We have a lot of interactive objects and lots of cache boxes which we barely use. Areas are too empty and lack of wildlife is disturbing. But unfortunately nearly all bad sides of this game exist solely because of a budget constrains.  But in this 5 hours you will become a part of a great little story about a simple man and a woman who are hiding from or battle their demons while keeping (unsuccessfully mind you) Wyoming from forest fires. It's presented to you through the brilliant voices of Henry (Rich Sommer) and Delilah (Cissy Jones). Their voice acting is amazingly fluid, natural and organic. Sometimes you actually feel like a part of their conversation but at the same time as a amazed listener. It would've made a great radio show, just this two talking.  Overall story is solid up until the end. The ending certainly is anticlimactic but at the same time it fits the story, developers wanted to tell us. Much like our heroes we've been tricked into thinking some events have more meaning than they really do. Maybe we should take a step back and take this piece of art for what it really is.  Pros: - Voice acting - Unity engine never looked better and more stylish. - Music - Dialogues  Cons: - Short gameplay time (due budget) - Underdeveloped characters (we have very little idea about who this people were before) - Lack of interaction and actual gameplay (due budget)  Overall: 7.5/10 Solid, beautifully crafted work.

My only gripe I have with Firewatch is that it took me 4.4 hours to complete, I really took my time too. I feel that a 4.4 hour long narrative (while it was a good one) is roughly worth 5 bucks. It's very rare these days to see a really well done single player campaign that keeps you wondering about the story as it develops, it was a breath of fresh air amongst the garbage heap of sequels being churned out these days with meager single player experiences bundled with them. I found the voice acting was very well done and the game looked great in the Unity engine, the music and effects were realistic too creating a good atmosphere that has you looking back hoping that nothing is following you. The soundtrack is very suitable it fits the setting perfectly. For a first release from an obviously small developer they've clearly set the bar a little higher in my opinion for any story driven campaign from here on out.

I was so disappointed in this game, ultimately.

If you're a person like me that enjoys the journey, regardless of the destination, Firewatch is for you. Fluent controlls   Beautiful graphics   Captivating story   Witty writing   Brilliant Voice Acting   Turt Reynolds   Firewatch is a narrative-driven game that takes place in a distant magical land called Wyoming. You play as Henry, a middle aged man with a troubled past and a sarcastic attitude. Become a fire lookout and meet your new boss Delilah, an equally sarcastic woman with a love for busting Henry's chops. As you progress through the game you'll start getting a feel for the woods and begin to familiarize yourself with your surroundings. Hike trails, climb rocks, and enjoy nature. But, not everything is right in the forest. Sudden events change the mood of the game in an instant. Now, the woods you've come to know don't feel so safe and serene anymore. It's up to Henry, with the help of Delilah, to try and save Shoshone National Forest. That is, if they can survive eachother.

Within the first 10 minutes this game was tugging on my heart strings. I don't write reviews very often, and I am going to preface with this, this game IS AN INTERACTIVE MOVIE. I pay $10-12 for movie tickets around here, so $17 for an interactive movie was worth it to me, but this is all subjective. I also am a total softy who gets very into stories so if you're not a person who cares much or finds yourself attatched to characters easily, just SKIP NOW!   The game puts you in the shoes of Hank/Henry, a man who's wife was diagnosed with early onset dementia. You attempt to work through it, take care of her, but the burden becomes too much. Her family steps in to begin taking care of her, distraught, and confused, you notice an ad for a job. You take it. This job is a Firewatcher.  The game throws you in already with your heart strings tugged on, and greets you with the beautiful wilderness. The game is all performed in a first person perspective, full body for maximum immersion. You look down, you got legs. You're greeted over the radio by your boss Delilah, who you end up forming quite the emotional bond with. You will laugh, you might cry, you'll feel the tugs a normal relationship comes with, including possibly upsetting her and causing her to step away for a few. As the game goes on Delilah notices fireworks being shot off, the park on a fire watch this is obviously a big no-no. She sends Hank to check it out, and the game progresses from there. Things get weirder, and weirder. I don't want to spoil too much as I don't believe in spoilers and think media like this needs to be experienced first hand. The game plays itself like an interactive indie thriller with AMAZING voice acting and beautiful scenery. With this preface and synposis I'll list pros-cons, please keep in mind these are all subjective and just my opinion!  Pros: + Extremely well done voice acting + Beautiful scenery, seriously, the colors, the lighting + A narrative that leaves you emotionally invested to the characters and their stories + The performance was outstanding for me, but on a 980 TI this is to be expected. + The game offers plenty of graphical and sound options. The default controls worked for me so I admit I didn't check them + A well rounded story with while a bit quick of an ending, one I found satisfying   Cons: - The game is short, it took me 3 hours pacing myself, but I was using the run key often and not enjoying the scenery as much as I could, I also skipped some trails. I do not find this an issue for the price paid but some may!  - The story at some parts felt rushed, skipping ahead a lot. But as I said, it very much feels like an indie thriller - I found there to be some lacking moments that could have been filled with more dialogue - It is hard to completely get attatched characters outside of Delilah, I felt underwhelmed or just uninformed in some instances -/+ Some people were not satisifed with the conclusion and I assume wanted a supernatural or more horrific ending. Perhaps some more interaction or choices that meant much, this isn't really a CON.. but I thought I'd put it here    I am sure others have many more and or better pros and cons but these are mine. For my $17 I feel like I have gotten my monies worth, I was very satisfied and enjoyed the experience. For others it may be best to wait for this to go on sale, for myself who loves story games and wishes to see more interactive narratives I do not mind paying the full price to support developers and encourage more!

Oh Firewatch how I had such high hopes for you. There are spoilers in this review so beware.  Firewatch definitely had some good things about it, but the bad outweighed the good.  Pros: - Gorgeous settings and art style. Every time I traveled to a new area of the map I was amazed by the beauty. The colors were great. I felt like I was there. - Excellent dialogue between the main characters. It felt natural and not really scripted. The voice acting plus the words spoken made for a superb combination that flowed nicely.   Cons: - The length was dreadful. I don't mind short games, but holy hell. I finished it in almost 5 hours, and I was going slowly I think. Midway through I felt the story wrapping up and I didn't want it to end abruptly. - That ending man, ugh. Everything that was interesting about the story just fell apart. How you do mess that up? By connecting all of these events with this one guy who was only mentioned in passing throughout the whole game. Then there is a fire and everyone goes home. Seriously? I understand that a big part of the story was running from your problems only to in the end have to face them and blah blah, but come on don't tease your players with gold and hand us crap. - The entire beginning segment was dreadful. It was a series of conversations with some choices here and there that really don't matter that much. You could at least give us a basic comic strip or something to work with. I can't emotionally connect to words spoken by characters I don't know. - The illusion of choice really bothered me. Pick a side! Either commit to player choice with ones that actually AFFECT the story or give you options for a different ending, or remove the choice element all together and allow me to experience who this man is with a solid story driven game. You get all these choices in the beginning and through your conversations with Delilah, and nothing to show for them. It's annoying. - The game is way too linear. You are given lush environments, beautiful landscape, and the works. But, it's a lie. You really can't drift far away from the set paths the map gives you. - Not enough of an incentive to replay. Give me hidden items, extra SOMETHING to work with. The only thing that I'll get with a second playthrough is oh I can choose this meaningless option that changes nothing in the game.  I bought this on sale, and I still overpaid. There are two kind of jump scares in this game. There is a part where you find this clipboard, and shortly afterward you get a strike to the head. The second is a missable one during a second trip to the abandoned cabin in that oven.

I'm recommending Firewatch. Is it a good story? Most definitely. Does it have an intriguing plot and characters? Without a doubt. Does it actually make you feel like you're hiking and exploring the wilderness? Well... for the most part yes. But is it a good GAME? ...Not really.  Pros: -THE WRITING. This is probably the best writing in a game I've ever seen, beating out most movies. It does such a good job of making you feel the relationship Henry and Delilah as it flourishes, and the way that it just hit every single emotion it possibly could was outstanding. -The Graphics. No, they're not the best in the world, but they can look very pretty at times and serves the game and it's tone well. -The Sound. From the little clicks that your radio makes to the sound of wildlife around you (even if you hardly actually see the wildlife itself) just further immerses you into the game.  And.... thats about it. That's all that's really noteworthy about this game, but boy what it does well it does WELL. Firewatch is probably the best game to play when you're tired after a long way and just want to enjoy something nice, calming and damn beautiful (in terms of the story).

This game is an interesting one to be sure.  I would have to classify this game as a exploration-themed walking simulator with dialogue options. Looking back on it I wonder how much of my choices really mattered, or if they changed anything. It would take another playthrough to find out. Of course minor things would have to change such as    Ned's tapes and documentation of what you say, and what the image of you would be like, and what you name the Tortoise (Bucket Jr. for me!)    Visually the game is simplistic but not to the point where it feels like laziness, though I did notice unusual clipping of moving things. Particularly of butterflies flying through rocks and a tortoise clipping into itself.    Along with you not meeting a single person and the only people you see being entirely black. In fact the entire woods seems almost entirely void of fauna, not once do I remember seeing a bird fluttering by, or even the scampering of a squirrel. Only butterflies.   The park itself is lovely and well designed, I very much enjoy the variety of settings available from the lush patches to the rocky mountaneous regions to the cave to the open grassland. It makes it all the more exciting to explore and discover.   Audio wise it's fantastic. The music does its job of inspiring awe and wonder when necessary, along with uneasiness and nervousness. Along with top notch voice acting. But, of course I can only speak for the dialogue I did hear, so there is the possibility they botched alternate dialogue I never heard. Also the sound of the environment and of animals (the few that you hear) work well.  Gameplay wise it feels reminiscent of a metroidvania in places, namely the 'You found this, now all this is available'. This would be more valuable if you could go back in time to before you have to 'put your nose to the grindstone' and really start working with these tools that you find. Also the inspect, while cute, doesn't do anything.   Along with that a great deal of the gameplay is dialogue options and I find myself wondering if any of it was worth the trouble. This is a make or break in this type of game, which can readily be seen in the recent Telltale lineup of games.    The story is well written and well paced with a great deal of suspense. I enjoy how it turns out overall, though there are some gripes I have.    There is an excessive use of red herrings and a great deal of things that are simply not explained. The fenced off area isn't explained explicitly, what happened to the girls isn't either (outside of them being attacked), along with the fact that Ned worked against himself by making himself known. Was this on purpose? Who knows? I certainly don't. And, again, I find myself wondering how much of it did I really impact? Did picking Bucket in comparison to Mayhem change that much? Did suggesting to have kids later rather than excitedly wanting kids change that much? Did anything you say to Delilah change anything at all (other than Ned's records)? Also, as a personal note, I didn't like the gap of days that were skipped. I would have preferred to complete day-to-day tasks with the option of skipping instead.    All in all, it's a good game though not quite what I was expecting from the trailer and what was built in my head. I envisioned this as a game where you play as a park ranger, looking out for things, exploring, and having day-to-day activities. This is instead a rather linear experience, but with the opportunity to go and explore on one of the earlier days it does make it interesting.

However, as a story telling game, Firewatch really does shine, it takes you through a different type of story, with a more realistic end considering what you endure, without going into any details. That's where I've seen the most complaints, in the ending, but as the game's story is simply about people, the ending is rather fitting for the adventure, you get to make up for yourself what you want this game to be. Firewatch is probably the best of the 'Walking Simulator' genre I've played yet. While there is a mystery plot that provides some set dressing, the real meat of the story is about two characters who have found themselves at a turning point in their lives, and deciding which direction to go. Each is informed by the events they experience in the woods of Wyoming.  Unlike a lot of scary, tension-filled games, Firewatch digs directly at real-life fears. Running from zombies or hiding from space monsters can be tense and scary in the moment, but the characters in Firewatch are coping with real problems that may yet strike me or my loved ones. At its core, the game asks 'what would you do?' in a somber and direct way that makes you wonder what your values really are.  Firewatch isn't targeted at hardcore gamers, or casual gamers, or even any audience we would normally thing of as a market. It is targeted at people who have reached the stage in life where the thought of something happening to your spouse or life partner is far scarier than the thought of it happening to you. It isn't a story about the people struck by tragedy, but about the people around them, who have to cope with the aftermath.  If you're in that category; if the most frightening thought in your life is having to find a way to go on after your happily-ever-after has been brought low by disease or disaster, pick up Firewatch at any price. It will be an experience you might not necessarily enjoy, but you'll appreciate. If not, give it a miss; if you just come for mystery and adventure, you're likely to be disappointed.

If Steam had a middle option for reccomendations, this is where my review would be, but as it stands I give Firewatch a Yes with a big ol' asterisk.  POS  Firewatch's visuals range from serene woodsy vistas to gorgeous pinkish sunsets.  The dialogue between Henry and Delilah is well written and acted well.  Latter half of the game is tense but not overbearingly so.  The presentation lends itself cutting out some fat, e.g. instead of you walking back to your watchtower, that game hard cuts to to the next day.  Afet you finish the game, you can get real life prints of photos you took with a disposable camera you find. Neat!  NEG  As you have read from literally every other review, the ending is lackluster. To explain why would spoil the events, but the jist of it is that the mystery that takes up most of the game does not resolve in a very satisfactory way, which some people are very unhappy about. Personally, I found it lackluster, but I didn't hate it. I understood the point, I just wish it was executed better. To end the way it did was unsatisfying - which may be the point? - but that doesn't make it good. Part of the problem may be the pacing. The game jumps rather quickly from Henry just chilling out doing his job to BIG MYSTERY in way that makes the way it slowly turns into the ending section jarring. My two cents, but I feel the game would benefit from being bigger, let the player get more into the feeling of being Henry out in the woods (mostly) alone. More menial tasks like yelling at the teenagers in the beginning. Actually observing and reporting potential fires. Warning some campers about their smoking. Firewatch suffers from its linearity because, like an unfortunate amount ofd the story based games, it doesn't benefit from being a game. Firewatch as a movie or short tv series or a book would have been the same experience. That said, it didn't ruin the experience for me, and I certainly won't be seeking a refund for a game I played to completion.  Some graphical and technical issues, nothing major.  Sometimes you are met with what the characters describe as an impasse but in a way that only makes sense in the context of the game's controls. Henry could easily finagle his way past that downed bridge. And, most egregiously, the concept of CLIMBING a fence is never brought up. It breaks immersion when what the characters percieve and what the player percieves are not in line and in fact conflict.  Again with the really bad portrayal of teenagers. Yeah, real life teenagers talk weird and are jerks, etc etc. But with how well written and acted Henry and Delilah are, it is very out of place for the two teenage girls to be the standard cliche Teen Slang and Not Caring About Mean Adults!  I wish I could have kept that radio past the first day. That ♥♥♥♥ was my JAM.  TL;DR  4 outta 5 I say play this game, or at the very least watch someone else play it. Definitely think about it if it goes on sale. I don't regret my 20 bucks on it. I really enjoyed 3 out of the 4 hours I played, and was only moderately displeased with the other 1.

First of all, I recommend this game but only to people who like this unusual genre of in-game storytelling. I personally was looking for something else, so I'm writing this review to tell others what they can and cannot expect. The graphics is my opinion high end for an indie game but cannot match AAA titles. Anybody who expects beautiful depictions of wilderness, open world and realistic graphics will be disappointed. The graphics is nice looking but with cartoon shaders and not very realistic. The game itself is an interactive story with lots of conversations and some mystery. It is best described, in my point of view, as a serious short novel turned into a video game. It is essentially about people who somehow got stuck and need to find a way to get on and find a new life. If you like the idea of putting such a plot in a video game, you might like this game.   If on the other hand you expect a large open world wilderness game with survival elements, as for example a totally misleading review at Arstechnica has suggested (which is why I bought the game in the first place), you will get none of this and will be disappointed. The wilderness is only a setting for the story that unfolds in the conversations with Delilah and by some things that occasionally happen. The game is also relatively short, around 5-6 hours of gameplay maximum.  Back to the story: The beginning is kind of horrible and there is some annoying psycho-babble later in the game, too, but overall I found the story interesting and well-executed. There is also some mystery and suspense in it. So I recommend the game although it's not the kind of game I'd usually like to play. It's worthwile and serious entertainment.

If your considering buying this game: understand what it is and what it isn't. You'll be much happier with your decision.  This game tells a story. The story is what it is; you can make choices about how you respond to it as it unfolds, but it's not a choose-your-own adventure with branching paths and multiple endings. I loved the story and felt the ending was very apt. Obviously some people feel differently, that's bound to happen with this type of game in the same way it does with any fixed narrative like a movie or book.  OK, now for my actual review: I was transported by this game and immersed right from the start. It's very well written, the dialogue felt authentic and the voice acting was excellent. The environment is stunningly beautiful and has wonderful ambiance, I could (and did and will) walk around in it for hours and hours. I felt that the story was powerful, moving and the ending was entirely appropriate.  Some have commented that they didn't feel the various elements of the story (particularly Henry's backstory and the events of the summer) had any real thematic connection, but I have to disagree. Without giving too much away, I thought there was a strong theme of loss and guilt tying everything together. It felt very genuine and human - mistakes you've made, time you can't get back.  This game has made a real impression on me in the way that certain special movies and books do, it invokes such a strong sense of place, time and feeling that it comes together as a whole transportive experience. I'm sure I'll come back to visit again and again.

I finished playing through Firewatch for the first time. It's a beautiful, suspenseful mystery game that twists at your heart as it tells a story about fidelity, trust, the wilderness, and early-onset dementia. I played through it in two sittings, in about the same amount of time it takes me to read a good book. I highly recommend it.  Four things to note, no spoilers:  1) The pictures you take with the camera you find can be retrieved later after the game. You don't need to use the camera to collect evidence; you just use it to remember your run after it's over.   2) My favorite feature of the game was the radio control. You can only speak to your boss, who is the only other character in the game you ever interact with, by holding down the left Shift key and scrolling with the mouse, just as if you were holding down a button on a two-way radio.  3) You control how your relationship with your boss, Delilah, develops based on what you say to her and if you choose to talk to her or not. I suspect that players can work out a few different endings based on which conversation tracks you choose, or if you choose not to say things.  4) You only have so much time to respond to Delilah - and the amount of time you have changes depending on how sensitive the subject you're broaching is. If your hands are busy when you're rappelling or holding your map and compass at the same time, you'd better not ALSO be trying to have a serious conversation, or else you'll miss stuff.

Overall I can recommend this game if it is on sale. With the good voice acting/script and the nice environments. A few things that could be improved:    The 'mystery' surrounding this game could have been developed more, by making the introduction of backstory, characters, and mechanics a bit faster. (eventhough you should take your time in this game)    Out of 80 possible days to work with, they skip around to show only about 5 days, I felt that if they used some more days then they could have developed a deeper mystery or added more. There is no real attachment to solve this mystery until you get to the last two days.   Eventhough there are a few things that fell short in my opinion I think this is a good game at a discounted price.

My take on the first game by developer 'Campo Santo'   Since its initial announcement, I have been pretty stoked about giving 'Firewatch' a try. And that is not because of the impressive developer cast behind the game, but because of the idea. After finally getting the chance to step into the hiking shoes of Henry, I was instantaneously blown away by the visuals. The way the Unity Engine is used to simulate the wilderness is something to behold. But don't let the beautiful cartoony exterior of the game fool you! Underneath it you will find well tuned gaming mechanics, which allow you to traverse the Wyoming wildes with ease. So far from a visual and navigational standpoint 'Firewatch' is solid, but what about the story?   The beginning sets a special tone that does not slowly ease you into the life of our protagonist, but on the contrary - it throws you in! While you are still trying to assimilate the predicament Henry is in, you find yourself atop of a watchtower in the middle of nowhere. As the player and the hero take in their new surroundings, the immersion intensifies itself by giving Henry a handheld radio with a voice on the other side - your supervisor Delilah. At this point you learn that not only does she speak, but your character does as well. This initial moment sets up the stage for the upcoming performance by the protagonist and the disembodied voice, as they try to protect the the wilderness from forest fires. This is immersive, because of the incredible voice acting by both actors portraying Henry and Delilah! During their talks the player controls the direction these conversations take and so he shapes Henrys personality, thus turning the player into his own version of the protagonist!   The developers at 'Campo Santo' have fused movement and storytelling mechanics with the visuals excellently, allowing for an immersive and emotional adventure, where you become your own unique Henry, while also forging a unique relationship with Delilah! Sadly we reach the ending quite abruptly, leaving us unsatisfied with the length and the conclusion to the story!   This is a game that is all about the journey, not the destination! I suggest playing the game more than once, so you can experience different conversations between Henry and Delilah as you make your way through the Wyoming wilderness. During my second playthrough I found new and exciting areas I had missed, and managed to develop an interesting new relationship between our heroes.  In conclusion - I give 'Firewatch' a very high recommendation for all fans of interactive storytelling games (or oldschool fans of the choose your own adventure books, like me).

This will be a generalized review that is spoiler-free.  I really like these kinds of interactive-narrative games, and I have played quite a number of them in the past few years. Firewatch is a title that is definitley a little more interactive than some of the more popular titles such as Dear Esher and mabye even Gone Home, but as beautiful as those games are I feel that Firewatch accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do and may appeal to a broader audience within that genre. How you take that experience in hits home more than just an interpretation of what did or didn't happen in the story; but instead has greater potential to affect you on an emotional level, and the decisions you make can perhaps allow you to observe your own life through it's lens. I would even argue that this interactive narrative, actually interacts with YOU the player.  Talking about the more tangible features of the Firewatch;  The pacing of the story is brisk with a number of fresh and concise plot turns here and there. The game also lets you play around a bit in it's world, and take it in at your own pace. You can observe the enviornment and whats in it, or consult your Delilah over the radio if you want more advice, insight, and story. It's up to you, and this makes it easier to craft a very unique interactive experience. There's crisp humor, some mystery, and even the feeling of inherent spookiness that just sort of comes with being isolated in the woods. That maybe you yourself are always being watched, an ironic spin on the game's title.  You come into this story knowing alot about your character from the start, and I feel that this allows the you to focus on how he might be thinking at this very moment, instead of being concerned with his past. Because of this, I feel that the intent of the developer was to set up the decisions you make to have more emotional weight to them for you, the player. Additonally, The external world itself changes as the game goes on, which I felt to be sort of a figurative display of how the characters are feeling internally, and how you might be too.   At any rate I'd highly reccomend picking this one up. It's price tag is more than reasonable considering the amount of work that went into it.

You know all those people saying it's really short? Well, they're 100% correct. While my time played says two hours, it's probably closer to three hours give or take, but I finished it in that time anyway.  Gameplay wise, it's a first person, naritive focused walking simulator. There is still plenty gameplay to be had here with different means of traversing the beautifully crafted landscape, but to it's core, it's a walking simulator. The game has set paths that you will have to follow, meaning your range of exploration is somewhat limited. Half of the map you can't explore because of this. If you're looking for an OPEN world game, this game isn't going to satiate you I'd imagine.   Presentation wise, the game uses a cell shaded artstyle, making it all look like a very well made cartoon. The graphics are pristine and the enviroments are beautifully made. The animations are smooth as all hell, they make the main character feel that bit more alive inside the world and also do a good job of showing his character from time to time. Where this game shines to high heaven is the sound design, which is arguably some of the best I've ever heard in a video game. The voice acting is phenominally done, making both the main characters feel extremely believable. You can trully tell how both character's feel, even though one of them comes from a walkie talkie.   This is a story game through and through, it lives and breathes for the story; but is it anything special? I'd definately say so. There is little that can be said that wouldn't expose the game's plot points, so excuse me if I sound vague. The game hooks you from start to finish, the opening alone made me feel like I just got punched in the gut. Midway through the game, stuff starts to get real as both you and the other person in the walkie talkie begin to get paranoid. The game's story eventually makes you feel uneasy, like you're always being watched, like any corner you turn might result in a swift rock to the head. There is a huge pile of mystery sneaked into what I thought was going to be a game about dealing with forest fires.   Personally, I didn't mind the ending.   Although I do feel like it kept things way vaguer than it should have done, leaving you feeling like there was something else you missed on your journey.     Despite it's short length, I do recommend this game. It's an amazing experience, one that tells you the story it wants to tell. While it's length and ending may be questionable, I still believe this game is something special to be had. I'd say it's overpriced just a bit, so I'd wait for a sale first before purchasing.

TL;DR Opened a box; Got stung by a bee. 9.5/10, would get stung again!  But seriously, this is more similar (but not the same) gameplay style like stanley parable, or imagine portal without the puzzles. It isn't fair to compare this game to those, but there isn't anything else i can think of to describe it:  It's a cinematic that you control. You're working in the forest, fire watching. Literally, in a tower in the woods, and the only contact you have is a walkie talkie. You walk around and a story just unfolds. You'll navigate to different areas to accomplish tasks from the story (which are interesting). I WISH I could give you more details and some of the feelings i felt so you can understand how much of an emotional roller coaster it was.   Yes, a video game.   This was the best part of the game. The story is awesome IMHO, but some would argue that. It's debateable according to some. Voice acting was superb. Like really, honestly, superb. The conversation system was revolutionary IMHO. Something like the choosing to talk, or tell or not tell what you see, will change how much depth a video game can have in the future (i hope). Graphics were oddly good looking and rough at the same time, just a bit. Like a little jagged, but still great with some gorgeous scenery. But this game is for the experience anyway. I took my time and it took like 4 hours, but I would do it again in a heart beat. These guys did superb.  TL;DR Opened a box; Got stung by a bee. 9.5/10, would get stung again!

No spoilers.  I really enjoyed my playtime. The artstyle is beautiful and cohesive, the world is wonderfully realised, the writing is fantastic and the voice acting is top notch. There is a fantastic atmosphere from start to finish, and the banter with Delilah really helped to set the mood throughout.  The term walking simulator automatically evokes a negative connotation in many people, including me, however Firewatch is one in a good sense. You are along to experience the story, however you actually experience it (and don't run around listening to story orbs, eugh). You have dialogue choices to make, you physically navigate the park and even use a map and compass to do some basic orienteering to find your way around. You are experiencing the story as it happens, and influencing it in minor ways along the way with your choices.  Its a fantastic mystery with a slight let down of an ending, and there isn't a whole lot of replayability for the price of admission. During my playthrough I took it for having a little more depth than it actually did, in regards to the objects you can pick up and the various interactive items in the game. The experience was memorable, if a little short.  Overall though, I quite enjoyed it, and would definitely recommend it.

This is such a difficult decision to recommend this game.  TDLR; Overall a fantastic game but misses beats in story and pacing, better to go in blind.  If you are after anything other than a story, go elsewhere. This game is as barebones as it comes, similar to something like 'Dear Esther' but with interation with a number of things around, usually in the form of informing the lady at the other end of the radio.  The game starts out with one of the most solid emotional connections ever in a game, I have never felt a connection to a few lines of text before, but this game crafts a fantastic relationship with only a few lines of text... Then it kicks you in the teeth.  At this point my (and probably your) expectations were (will be) at a very high point, this continues to sky rocket for about another hour or two, then things start to get revealed and questions start to get answered and the game falls so far so quickly you will barely realise it's wrapping up before you are out of the wildy and back in the menu.   The graphics are gorgeous, the particles, skyboxes, enviromental assets and various bits and bobs you can touch and read are all fantastic, some of the best in this art style.  The voice acting and writing (for interations between the two main characters) are perfect, amazing talent, really brings the characters to life, you want to meet Delilah so badly due to how realistic she feels and sounds, right now im considering playing through a second time just to choose different options and try learn more about her.  The story, as mentioned before starts insanely strongly but falls too far too quickly and is a real dissapointment which is an immense shame because of how fantastic everything else is. I really hope there is some DLC or something, ANYTHING, to flesh this out some more.  Do i recommend? Yes, but under the pretence that you go in blind. Don't watch trailers, don't get all hyped up from reviews, infact don't read reviews at all. The less you know about this game the better, much like in 'The Begginers Guide' because the more you hype this up inside your head the more dissapointed you will be coming out.  Overall a fantastic game but misses beats in story and pacing, some more fleshing out would have been better or a different ending/reveal. (It's so hard to say this about something I wanted to love so badly).

Pros: Engrossing story that is EXTREMELY well-written and voiced. Mood is frequently tense. Adult themes are explored and the game doesn't baby sit you. You are left to find your own way with, literally, a compass and a map. Story is, mostly, well-paced. Graphics are cartoony, but nice. Very few technical issues.  Cons: Story line is EXTREMELY short. About 5 hours with some wandering around in between. Could probably be finished within 2-4 hours. Some of the plot reveals feel sudden and very rushed. Some plot holes are created as the game tries to trick you away from the actual villian. Many storylines that are hinted at are either never explored or I missed them in my play through. This does not create any replay value as I will be trudging through a story I've already heard with the hopes of simply stumbling upon missed notes. Occasional frame rate dips, graphical errors, and hit detection problems.  MINOR SPOILER BELOW***  The ending was crap. Sorry, but it was. I could have guessed it, but the absolute lack of a twist made me believe it could not have been correct. Even after the 'big reveal,' which lasts mere seconds, I spent the entire ending sequence waiting for the actual ending. 'That could not be it' I told myself. There had to be more. There wasn't. I even sat through the credits in the hopes of something. Anything.  Thus, this was the biggest problem with the game. The ending does not explain the purpose of the story that was just told. Why go through all that? And every single time the game led you to what felt like a massive reveal or something epic, it turned out to be something plain and wholely expected.  My biggest hope is that the storyline does truely change depending on how you play it and, because I played a genuinely nice character I set forth the story that was told. Otherwise, this was an example of a great, unique concept with mediocre execution.

Is this game short?  Yes  Does it have gameplay I'll enjoy?  Probably not  Well ♥♥♥♥, does it at least have a plot?  Holy dear mother of God yes it does.  This game can be beat in a short amount of time. But as I was going, I thought of it like this, translate this game into a novel and you will probably reach the full length required for something to be considered a novel. Compare to the price which is about $20 and it is incredibly worth it. Firewatch is stunningly beautiful with a plot that is thick with undertones and moments of true suspense. Though I don't know if decision making plays a huge part of the game, dialogue feels dynamic and real.   However, since it's a strong narrative game, it's very linear. There isn't much to explore apart from when the game lets you go on a new path, but on the first trip through any area it's pretty awe inspiring.   However, I wish I could've been more immersed but it's to be expected that the game isn't about you right from the get go. A succinct character is introduced with a dynamic backstory. There's no reason for you, as the player, to think that you are in any way Henry. The only thing you are is a choice for his dialog and the engine that drives him. I think that if you go into the game thinking this, you'll have an awesome experience of being a part of a great visual story with a thrilling conclusion. The best part is, I don't think anyone's story is necessarily the same. Maybe your desicions give you better outcomes, but maybe they don't.   For some, this can be a very introspective game, making you look at yourself and your own relationships.  If you're looking for a great narrative game, then I highly reccomend this, but if you're looking for something with cool gameplay or skill based gameplay, look elsewhere. Firewatch is a visual story, so just let yourself enjoy it and get caught up in the emotions.
