First of all, big props to Campo Santo for making such a lovely, rich game - at first try!  As I am writing, I finished the game just 3-4 minutes ago and just looked up on the internet what other people thought of the game. I will make this review spoiler-free.   Personally, I liked it. It is a visually stunning-looking game and is absolutely admireable in regard to script and voice-acting. Future games of same or similar genre should take note from Firewatch. Because in my honest opinion, the script and voice-acting of this game is a new milestone in videogame history and very pleasing and feels real.   Now, about the game itself. To me this game is about the journey, not the destination. The game builds up a lot of tension and mystery which is creepy at times but in a good enough way to keep you intrigued. The relationship between the protagonist, Henry, and his boss, Delilah, feels genuine and thanks to the script is a fun experience to witness. The game is very simplistic when it comes to controls, which is fine. For a story-rich 'walking simulator' this type of game does not need elaborate controls. There is a gimmick in the game that lets you pick up items and 'examine' them, exactly like L.A. Noire. Except in L.A. Noire at actually had a purpose. It does not really have any impact in Firewatch other than letting you examine certain items (for reading books and notes). It is a thing I feel they could have explored some more.   The story itself is odd. As of yet, I cannot decide whether I found it weak or strong. The mystery and paranoia is amazing and really makes you think about what you should say/report/do. Throughout the game I was conspicuous to whom was creating all this mayhem. However, the ending somewhat falls flat in the last act when it is revealed what was going on. As I said earlier, to me, this game was about the journey, and not the destination. The journey is amazing, the destination is a slight let-down.   I have read a lot of comments about this game. It seems a lot of people seem dissatisfied with relationship between Henry and Delilah. To me I was not surprised what happens between them, it is somewhat implicit and obvious within the game design and story-telling. I do not think I can say anything more about that, without spoilers.   So, last verdict. Firewatch is a beautifully looking game, without a doubt. Its cartoonish looks fit perfectly for what it is. By the way, again, BIG props to Campo Santo for making such beautiful sunrises and sunsets. Wow. Gameplaywise Firewatch is simplistic with slight 'process' in terms of equipment that eventually gets 'upgraded'. As said before, the script and voice-acting is superb and was the selling-point for me when I first watched the gameplay trailers about 10 months ago. The ending is a slight letdown.   Despite the anti-climactic ending I would give Firewatch 7.5/10  I enjoyed Firewatch A LOT. It was a charming, fun little game. Steam says I have only played it for 3 hours, which I do not know is true (I have run it through steam and desktop directly and I do not think steam has recorded my gametime when I did not run it through steam). I think it took me between 4-5 hours to complete.   I sincerely hope we get to see something more from Campo Santo. Not necessarily a sequel, but definitely something more with same type of script and voice-acting.

Do not go into this game expecting an open world, rich mystery story. It is a 4/5 hour narrative driven adventure.   I have to admit i was slightly disppointed with the ending of this game, as well as it's length. But thats purely due to my personal taste.  However, the narrative, voice acting, visuals and optimisation (at least in my experience) were superb, and thats where this game excels. Purely due to the fact that i wanted so much more of this title is a testament to how likable and realistic it's characters and setting was.   I feel like the developers could have got a lot more out of the scenery and utilised the way that the narrative was framed more effectively, e.g. the days were counting down yet this took away a sense of pacing. I would have liked to fill out some of the mystery (which was great while it was still mysterious) with a few more mundane days, maybe with some varied activities and optional tasks to do on these 'filler days'. This way, the players can explore and interact with the landscape rather than just utilising it for the plot.   I actually don't think a mechanic like a scrapbook would have been out of place in this title, we already have photo's which was a fun idea. If there were plants, animals and samples to record and collect this would have been a great 'mundane' optional experience that would fill out the sense of seclusion and properly feel like a retreat to nature.   I throughly enjoyed my nearly four hours of play, and think that the developers have done something quite bold and refreshing, however i still think that the experience could have been supplemented with a few tried and tested adventure game/rpg mechanics.

Pro:  - It's very atmospheric. - Graphics suit the style and atmosphere well. - Great storytelling. - Nice sound-design. - 'Cozy game', because you don't feel completely alone (D.) and all you gather is part of your home later. - The first 3/4 of the game are building up much tension. - The arguments between D. and H. are awesome and funny. Firewatch is a beautiful walking simulator, wrapped around an engaging growing relationship, wrapped around a pretty gripping mystery. And you can steal people's alcohol.  The graphics are gorgeous and a big selling point. It seems like everywhere you turn is a work of art, and I had fun pulling out the in-game camera to take pictures of sunsets and vistas. I love games such as Borderlands which are stylised in a unique way, so this really stood out. It looks almost painted.  The conversational system was a good idea, and felt pretty natural -- instead of getting locked into a conversation screen, you pursue branching conversations while walking around the environment, and you can phone up your radio buddy to start conversations about most of the things you find. The dialogue is well-written, well-acted, and often hilarious. The main characters' relationship did seem to develop depending on what I said -- I'm looking forward to playing again as a huge jerk and seeing what's different. Even inconsequential-seeming dialogue choices sometimes paid off later on in small ways that made the world feel a lot more immersive.  The story kept me interested and guessing, and broke my heart in a couple of places, and I really came to care for the characters. There's no combat or puzzles, but the mystery and characters keep pulling you along, and it's easy to grow fond of the environment you're hiking around in. My one gripe is that travel sometimes got frustrating when I found myself lost off the side of a trail, and had to double back. But I've never had much of a sense of direction.  It's short, but it's short like Gone Home -- the game is about the right length to tell the story, and no longer.  I recommend trying it out, I had a great time.

Just wanted to give a quick spoiler free review for Firewatch since i enjoyed it so much, just gonna outline the core features and my opinions on them  Story - 6/10 I enjoyed the story, didn't find myself predicting alot of the twists like with some stories. I really enjoyed just the laid back feeling in the beginning and the ramping up towards the mystery. But i feel the ending could have been better. Then again i had emotionally invested myself into the story and just wanted the conclusion i thought i should be able to have chosen. For the game itself yes it is a very short game, but if the developers had stretched it out i feel like it would have made it worse. Seems to me this is the kind of game best completed in one playthrough or at least one day.  Sound - 7/10 Great. The voice actors are amazing and really helped me connect with the characters it felt like the dialogue and interchange between the main characters was very fluid and not forced. Didnt find myself hearing the same old sound effects that other games use so that was refreshing. Music could use more work felt like there were only a few tracks that looped every 6 or so seconds.  Graphics - 7/10 (Played on max) Love the art style, plenty of detail in objects that you can pick up, read and even manipulate the 3D model to look at all angles. Textures may have needed a little more work but the game isnt going for photorealism it uses alot of light and shadows to set the scene. Reminds me very much of The Long Dark in a way.  Gameplay 6/10 - Just running around a forest really, no jump button just using LMB RMB and SPACE to interact with the world for the most part. But thats all the game really needed.  Replay value - 1/10 This isnt a game i plan on playing again anytime soon, not because i dont like this game, i just feel there would be not so much more to do to warrant another playthrough. The only thing i can think of is to go back and choose the other dialogue options to see what difference it might make.  My opinion 7/10 overall. Very nice game for me it was worth the price even for such a small amount of gameplay, took me little over 5 hours to complete the game working at a medium pace trying to absorb and read everything i could and activating as much dialogue as i could by interacting with points of interest. If your a fan of a nice immersive story then yes buy this game. If your expecting any kind of 'action' then no don't buy it.

Well, to make a long story short, I enjoyed this game. I would definitely reccomend it, if only as a view into one of the best examples of storytelling in video games to date. But, like many other people, I have a few problems.  In many ways, this game lived up to my expectations, but not all of them. It was gorgeous, with a well-written story and fully realized environment. I, for one, never expected it to be open world, and it wasn't. That wasn't a problem for me. What was a problem for me, however, was that the game seemed a little empty. At the end, I felt like there was something missing. Some sort of closure I didn't get. But, I think that was supposed to be the intention all along. This game is probably one of the more realistic ones, in terms of story, and for that reason, the ending is similarly realistic.  Now, this isn't to say that I disliked the time I spent with the game. I most certainly enjoyed my five-ish hours with it. I wish there was an option where, at the end of the game, I could explore the park at my leisure, but there is not. Regardless, I'm excited to see what else Campo Santo will do in the future, and while Firewatch may not have been everything I hoped it to be, I do not feel like I wasted money on it. This is one of the few games I could see myself playing again.

Edit: Also, the soundtrack is absolutely stunning, while it's not used much throughout the game it is used to help build tension, relief or revelatory moments as most of the time the game instead focuses on the dialogue and the incredible sounds of nature to help build the atmosphere. However, when the soundtrack is around it is haunting and really helps make the moments it is used in special.

NOTE: I DIDN'T FINISH THE GAME, I ONLY PLAYED THE GAME FOR ABOUT ~1 HOUR BEFORE REFUNDING DUE TO REASONS I WILL SPEAK OF IN THIS REVIEW. THERE'S ALSO A TL;DR AT THE END OF THIS REVIEW    I was really looking forward for Firewatch. The trailers they released made me so very hyped for the game. The game looked amazing, the characters looked full of personality, and the story sounded very interesting. A day before the game was released, many websites released their reviews for the game. The reviews were all praising the game for being amazing so, I took their word and took the plunge to buy the game.  I started the game and instantly I saw the slick menu. The options menu is lacking of a FOV slider but I didn't really get too bothered by this but, I know some people who will get bothered with this. I launched the game and it started off with a very well written backstory. Even though this was only about ~10 min long, I really got intrigued to continue with the story.   After the starting is over, you start the main part of the game you meet a girl named Delilah. She talks with you through a walkie-talkie. She's a really big part of the story. Hearing the main character, Henry, talk to Delilah is probably one of the best part of the game. The connection they have and the conversations are really fun to hear.  You're probably wondering why I gave this game a 'No' after writing all these nice things. Despite all of this, the gameplay is ♥♥♥♥ poor. The whole game is very linear, you can't take other paths to get to each objective. Places that look like you can go are either blocked by rocks or invisible walls. This whole game is beautiful and all I want to do is explore the forest and take paths my way. I think this game would be better if this could be done. I also find the speed you walk/jog quite slow.     TL;DR   Firewatch has a beautiful story, visuals, and very live characters. All of this is hindered due to the fact that the gameplay is just a slow paced and linear walking sim.   I won't give this game a score since I didn't finish it. I think just marking this game as a 'No' is good enough.

This game is wonderful. Know what you're getting into: a story-focused game with great writing and voice acting, and an immersive atmosphere packed with lovely design details.  Yes, the gameplay is mostly walking around and exploring the environment as the story unfolds, but that's okay — adding in elements like puzzles, mini-games, etc. would just distract from the story.  People complain about the length, but it felt right to me; think of it like a good mini-series. It took me about 4.5 hours, about a third of which was spent poking around taking in the little details like the fake vintage book covers. It was worth every bit of $20 for me personally, but if you're just going to rush through it then I think you're missing the point.  Oh, and go into the settings before you start and turn off the position indicator on the map! I wish I had have known that earlier — it makes the game much more immersive.

SPOILERS INCLUDED!  With some mixed reviews, but generally positive overall, I was a little unsure about buying this one. Still, I quite like walking games with strong dialogues.   The plotline – a creepy-looking mystery in a Wyoming state park in the late 80s – also seemed unusual and eye-catching. At just over C$22 I thought I’d give it a go and decided not to read the reviews much further so as to keep an open mind.  The pros:  The conversations you have with Delilah are the strongest parts of the game. There are some moments when I chuckled here. For example, Delilah tells you all the cache boxes are coded ‘1234’ because it made life so much easier – a neat, realistic touch.   The on-radio relationship between the two is believable, as well as the guilt Henry feels because of Julia’s condition.   The other strength is the world you find yourself in. The rendering of the park is nicely done and the conditions, depending on the time of day, add a great deal to the overall atmosphere. When you get into the caves there’s also a real sense of claustrophobia and some moments of disorientation. The woods can be eerie at night, and the sounds effects of nocturnal scurrying sometimes a little unnerving.  Some nagging points: You collect lots of notes that serve no ultimate purpose. The same is true for the photos you take to build up “evidence” as they only provide some images during the end credits.   The walking about can become repetitive, taking you back through areas multiple times. You start to realise that much of the playable world is quite limited, especially when it’s the fifth time you’re heading to a destination via Jonesy Lake.  It was also a disappointment that larger use of the caves wasn’t made. It would have been neat to have several levels to explore and really broaden things out.  The scientists’ base, their arrival and fate is left unexplained. Indeed, Delilah even says she didn’t know about their arrival or the fact that they’d managed to fence off a massive slice of the park even though it’s close to her watchtower. That's odd because she’s paid to pay attention to what goes on in the park.   The cons:  The gameplay is really short – I completed the game in just 4 hours and that ending, arriving as it does so soon, also finds the plotlines collapsing like a soggy soufflé.   You see Ned, a previous firewatcher, had taken over a scientists’ site and used their equipment (and his own) to listen into Henry and Delilah’s conversations. He’s the one trying to spook Henry and Delilah. He breaks and enters; beats Henry unconscious with a rock; attempts to kill Henry through starvation by locking him the caves; and finally commits arson with the intent to destroy evidence.  So why did Ned go all ‘Friday 13th, part XXIV: Michael Myers takes a vacay in Wyoming’? Because he thinks the pair has become too inquisitive about the fate of his son, Brian, whom Delilah had allowed to stay with Ned some years before, despite it being a breach of park rules.   You see Ned was a poor father who drank and insisted his introverted boy accompany him while camping, climbing and caving. And it was during the caving that Brian fell to his death. Instead of reporting this, Ned decides to just hide out in the wilderness near the scene of the accident.   Oh and he doesn’t bury his boy – he just leaves the body in the cave… so there’s that.  After playing the game I thought about the conversations between Henry and Delilah that revolved around Ned and his son – the ones that provoked Ned’s sociopathic behaviour. They last no more than five or ten minutes and lack the depth of those discussions that revolved around Julia.   But the greatest failing relates to the relationship between Henry and Delilah. It seems so crucial, but has little influence on proceedings. In the end it suddenly appears very linear and, if there is any real surprise to the game, it’s that.   The price:  For an indie game at C$22 I’m not expecting over 100 hours of gameplay with all the bells and whistles on. But 4 hours is a let-down. Once a game is over $20 the excuse of ‘what did you expect for that price?’ doesn’t sit right with me.   The developers clearly worked hard on what they put together, but I suspect the curse of the indie game struck – that an alpha/beta product was placed on the market as the resources to deliver the envisaged concept simply dried up.   Score: 3/10 and a great shame because there was some superb potential here. That’s why I felt really disappointed with the game and thought I’d try my hand at reviewing it.

For a game whose opening chapter covers ground ranging from the use of illegal fireworks at peak fire season to anxieties of dislocation and purposelessness—and whose narrative auguries are quite literally forecasted—Firewatch seques the player into its world with surprising gentleness. Chris Remo (alongside a rather rhetorical choice system) ferries us through Henry’s emotional traumas with a subtly and appropriately bruised score; the notes of which are, as with the cosmic heartsick of his work on Gone Home, acutely tender. Moreover, Firewatch‘s willingness to tear the bandage from Henry’s past for the player in a single and relatively quick motion, detailing but not dwelling on it, keeps the game’s prologue from feeling heavy-lidded and mawkish, despite the fact that we find ourselves in the Wyoming wilds after a series of fades in and out from black akin to the false awakenings of a hot, restless morning.  While I question the need for this front-loading of expositional player choice, as it could have been embedded in the system already present through the rest of the game via Henry and Delilah’s radio conversations, in which the player makes these same kinds of choices anyway when deciding how to respond to her friendly inquiries about his past, it is Delilah and not Julie (Henry’s estranged but omnipresent wife) who gives the story its glow. Indeed, her kittenish but openly clawed charisma is clear within seconds of Henry’s lifting the walkie talkie from its cradle and betraying his greenness both as a fire watch and a lost pup. Campo Santo‘s intent here, as with the moments preceding it, appears to be to establish a directness with the player—to characterize the experience early, and with candour, so as to afterward surprise them on level ground. The virtue of this strategy is that the compounding mystery later in the game feels genuinely mysterious and not merely masked. The story is able to play its hands, in other words, without resorting to tricks.  This is not to say that Firewatch is without its distortions. Artist Olly Moss‘s pastel forest, flush with gossamery midsummer heat, assumes both a buoyancy and the monodimensionality of a cutout animation, the effect of which bending more toward one or the other depending on the time of day or night; the shadows of the aspens convoluted in the wind or rotating as if by sun or moondial. When the plot begins to cash in on its earlier thunderstorms and the ilk and takes turns toward hazards ostensibly more serious than fires, the weather, and “problem bears”, this environment begins to suffocate Henry and Delilah’s (and the player’s) thoughts. Prior to these turns, Delilah’s radio assistance reliably keeps Henry par for the course and in bright spirits, but little by little her words lose their irreverent good nature and become kindling for his paranoia. (And vice versa.)   I won’t ruin what results, except to say that Henry and Delilah are eventually able to piece together a kind of cracked mirror, thematically speaking, of their relationship with one another. But while said turns give the game urgency and mystery, its most urgent, universal questions go unresolved. This is so by necessity and not design, though Campo Santo’s awareness of the fact makes the distinction as thin as air at elevation. Firewatch, like all good stories, only partially satisfies; it knows that the answers to the fundamental questions it raises are less crucial than their pursuit. The central “quests” for these characters, to put it in videogame terms, precede the opening credits and survive the closing ones. In this sense the Wyoming wilderness, and its ‘watch’, are a game not only for the player but for them as well: a remove from reality both geographical and psychological, only one of these evidently a success. (When Delilah admits her own storied hardships in response to Henry’s, declaring that the two of them are “both ♥♥♥♥ed up”, she does not say “were”.)  As both a game experience and a narrative one, Firewatch shows a level of restraint rare for the medium—especially when considering its subject matter. This restraint is, however, despite the developer’s good intentions, the reason for its shortcomings as much as its strengths. On one hand, Henry and Delilah’s patent need for one another is painted in neither saccharine nor manipulative strokes (even fading to black rather than showing the one moment in which direct transmissions of their intimacy are sent and received in seriousness); on the other hand, the game hits some of its most critical beats without giving them quite enough space to satisfyingly breathe. Once the plot is in stark ascent toward its climax, the experience is remarkably tense; but this intensity gains too much momentum without pause, I think, and with too much haste, the game’s apparent concern over trespassing on the player’s time such that it sacrifices its own. These self-awarenesses do not stop the game from excellence, but may be ultimately what stop it short of greatness.  Even so, the takeaway here may be how small a difference that makes. Firewatch is, semantics aside, thoroughly beautiful work. Subtle, but also confident; and able to balance devastation with rejuvenation, to handle difficult subject matter with sensitivity and frankness, but also humour and a healthy measure of uncertainty; it is, really, a class act. From a purely “game” standpoint, yes, the vast majority of Firewatch is spent walking, talking and listening; and the environment which envelopes these activities is as much a solicitude as solace. Crows quill the treeline and shadows warp the flaxen ground and thirsting creeks. At dusk and dawn particularly, the forest often resembles the very thing the player is tasked with protecting it from. But if reality as we experience it is, as the game implies, so much of our own making, then scorched earth is a lost cause only if we apostacize it. If we can accept what is for what is and not paint failure as the end, perhaps we can be as forests, or avatars in a game: regenerated, and better with each restart.

Firewatch is principally, a mystery story. It takes place in the wilderness of Wyoming and you are Henry. You come in control at a crossroad in his life as his wife has an early form of dementia, and he's had some recent trouble involving his drinking problem and the law. He escapes to the Firewatch post as he can't quite come to grips with his situation and the solitude might have done him well.  After a two-day hike to the watch tower, you 'meet' the boss, Delilah, via handheld radio. This vehicle of communication is literally your only means of any sort of social interaction as you're quite alone with only the trees and wildlife to keep you company. Or, are you?  The game allows you to respond to situations and dialog with several choices, and playing through, there's that personal touch like you're making a difference.  Your first day is a bit tough as you have to deal with some skinny dipping college girls—I said tough didn't I? Though the interaction is never face-to-face, you shout empty threats at them across the pond in an effort to get them to stop being litter bugs and shooting off fireworks. With the addition of a far-off interaction with another hiker, the day was rather uneventful until you returned to your watch tower. It was very clearly trashed maliciously.  From then on, when Henry isn't enjoying his summer solitude in the woods, there's an air of mystery as strange things happen. It is all brought to a head when he discovers a clipboard with transcripts of his and Delilah's radio conversations out by the lake! Shortly after, he's knocked out and the makes of a conspiracy start to unfold.  Much of the gameplay was running errands for Delilah up to this point, but it quickly escalates into investigating an unknown fenced region in the middle of the woods and the eventual abandoned caves.  So much of what you find points strangely toward a human experiment involving two people left in isolation for an extended period of time. Even more mystery unfolds as those girls were reported missing and suspicious calls, claiming to be Henry, report that Delilah knows what caused the forest fires that quickly swallow up the area.   The conclusion comes all too quickly, and it honestly, left something to be desired.   The story-crafters did an excellent job in building it all up as I was hooked in wanting to know more. Once those final credits made their crawl across the screen, it then left me wanting more, actually disappointed since—this—was it.   You're given a disposable camera mid-game and it seemed like the perfect opportunity to document the strange occurrences. Even more so when evidence began to point at your character's guilt! Those photos' ultimate purpose was a bit of a slap to the face as it really makes you feel foolish.  I could only think of all the strange things that had happened to Henry.   In gameplay, I found charts with character traits written in. Indicating that whomever the author was, specifically believed that Henry was gullible. Even knew his history prior to joining the Firewatch program.   On those charts, Delilah was also mentioned to still be in a relationship despite her tale of how she came to be at her post. She seemed to be just as innocent, but she admitted to fudging a report to avoid talking to the police.   Things weren't adding up.   Regardless, the ending was so simple.   I enjoyed the game and was engrossed in it's execution. Running from one end of the forest down to the lake front, and back up to my tower as quick as my feet would carry me. The character development between you and your only emotional anchor, Delilah, is effectively the main attraction next to the mystery that surrounds the woods. It was so engaging, I really liked the snarky wit and chemistry her and Henry shared. The visuals were beautifully cell-shaded and the ambiance really immersed the player into the environment. From the first person perspective, scaling cliff walls during those intense moments, there were several opportunities I was sure something dangerous was going to be waiting for me.   It was the equivalent of a good book in terms of entertainment. Being able to choose my immersion level meant I could look at everything, or just follow the objectives. It was neat reading and investigating whatever I could put my hands on. Putting together these details into this side-narrative next to the one built into the game.  Ultimately though, it was a book that ended in such a way that it actually made me angry.   Not so much at the journey, as it was great ride. But at myself for being so invested.  It's a 'life is tough' tale, and really, that doesn't bother me. It's the fact that my choices may have warranted different responses, but played no part in the ending at all.  Games made by Telltale like 'the Walking Dead' series make your choices matter by potentially losing favorite characters and changing the outcome of the story. Whatever that may be, your crafted it with your own morals and values. Firewatch fell flat in that regard, and it should have been evident to me early on with the prologue choices. Plus, I don't think it was worth the $20 price tag. I knocked it out in 3 hours of gameplay and there wasn't much 'playing' besides running back and forth while making superficial choices. If it had had more substance, or it hadn't skipped in the number of days, and just allowed me to explore freely in the mean time between chapters; maybe I would have felt more justified.  I walk away from this game conflicted that it could have been better, but then I remember that it did it's job of engaging me. It had me with the little adventuring prior to the great mystery and the with the interactions with Delilah. I didn't want to miss a single one. Oh, and Turt Reynolds, too.  The mystery, despite not meeting my highly imaginative conclusions, was something so simple I had dismissed it early on in favor for something grand. Accustomed to other story driven games where there are always aliens and secret societies in the background, it ruined me for Firewatch's epilogue I think.   Delilah beckoned to the hopeless romantic in me. There was an authentic and convincing nature with the voice acting. Even though in hindsight, she may have been behind it all, in some way—says the conspiracy theorist in me.  This story doesn't wrap up neatly the way you might want it to, but it does in it's own way. It really was an experience. It would be worth an afternoon play through to learn about these characters and delve into the shady nature that looms in those Wyoming Woods. Enjoy the visuals, be absorbed by the isolation, and feel sad for the kid. Only you should do it after a Steam sale of Firewatch.

Even though I played this game on my crappy gaming laptop which hardly managed the medium settings and the audio was delayed sometimes, it turned out to be one of the most profoundly captivating gaming experiences I've had in a long time. If you've read Thoreau's 'Walden' you will feel right at home here, although the tranquility of solitary life in the woods is constantly subverted through a masterfully crafted undercurrent of awe, dread, joy and the superbly voice-acted dialogues of Henry and Delilah. This is a game that you won't play for the challenge of solving complicated puzzles or achieving a goal as quickly as possible, but rather a game that you play for the incredibly immersive experience of its dense, unique atmosphere of a slowly unraveling mystery in the North-American wilderness. Even though it's a short adventure, it's one that will stay in your thoughts long after its credits have rolled. Instead of providing simple answers, this game dares to ask questions and leave you wondering, inviting you to think for yourself, about your morality and your decisions. And it is one of those rare games that truly made me be absolutely uncertain if I had made the right decision, because the options were as complicated as life, and I love it for that. This game is not for everyone, but don't let the short duration fool you - this game lasts much longer than the actual play-time, especially when kicking back, closing your eyes and listening to the slightly melancholic soundtrack after a long day. Then you're right back there, in the Wyoming wilderness, hiking through woods that never seem to show you the same marvelous face of distant mountains, infinite pine trees, rocky canions and breathtaking sunsets twice.

Firewatch is a mystery. A good mystery, at that. So what makes a good mystery? Interesting characters. Interesting setting. A sense of tension that grows until the catharsis at the end. A story that keen minds will unravel just in advance of the plot is revealed.  It's as replayable as a favorite movie or a loved book; you will almost certainly remember what happens once you get into it, but it's so beautiful and engaging that you won't mind. Henry and Delilah will feel like old friends, or enemies, the next time you see them.   PRO Art - It's beautiful. Like playing a painting. It pays attention to how light and motion color the world around us, like an impressionist painting, but with the beautiful colors and emotional bias of expressionism.   Voice Acting - The voice actors for this game are phenomenal, and there's an incredible intimacy in communicating by radio or telephone. It's like being in bed at night, phone cradled to your ear with a friend or loved one on the other end.  Story - The game has a story it wants to tell and an emotional impact that it wants to make, and it succeeds with both.  But what about it being... Short - If you're expecting a long AAA title, this isn't it. This lasts about as long as a long movie, and you should treat it as such. If the price point bothers you, check out what a theater ticket and a beverage would cost you.  Directed - Because it's telling a story, it wants to direct you from point to point and not give you a lot of time to explore the scenery. If it gives you an indication to use the radio to report you are ready, resist the urge and explore. The game will take you to most of the locations, but there are some fun things to explore.   Campo Santo did an amazing job witht his, and if you catch it on sale, you have no reason not to get it. That said, I waited until it was full price to buy it and I'm glad I gave them my money.

Firewatch is an absolute triumph. Beautiful and grand, you exist in and explore vistas that will take your breath away. The animations are top notch, and the texturing and color palette are odd yet remarkable. Hard to describe. You almost get the feeling you're in an adult-themed Pixar film, if that makes sense. The voice acting IS SOME OF THE BEST IN ANY GAME, EVER. Which is good, because the quality of the voice work would be a real make-or-break factor for this title. Details abound that will captivate you in this world, some you may not even notice at first (like how your character, Henry, has a difficult time scaling rock faces at first, heaving and dragging himself up, but becomes more proficient with time).  Then the story starts to unfold, and it is absolutely gripping. The atmosphere in Firewatch is spellbinding, and I was left at the edge of my seat with tension and a feeling of impending doom more often than almost any other game I've played in recent memory. There's a certain vulnerability to being alone, in the woods, with only one tenuous link to another human being. Campo Santo plays this solitude along with incredible art and music to deliver a complete package and exhilarating experience.  There's the oft debated question 'Are games art?' If you're still on the fence about that, Firewatch will make you a believer.  Oh, and a lot of folks seem to be complaining about the ending and the interaction with your supervisor at the end. I, for one, appreciated it. Because it was a real ending, not a video game ending. I won't spoil it, but I think us as gamers get used to common tropes and, eventually, get dissapointed when a game doesn't fulfill these things. Sometimes the climax isn't something that would be found in thousands of other games. Sometimes things don't work out the way you want them, even in this virtual space.   I love this game, and I appreciate its honest ending.

First off, shave off around 5hrs on my gameplay total. Accidentally left it running one night.  This game is exactly what I have been looking for to satisfy my need for a game that is story driven, not hack and slash driven. It is slow paced, full of story, and quite interactive in regards to conversation and elements in the environment. It has beautiful graphics, really compliments the feel of the game. Voice acting is spot on. Music is very fitting with how the various moments feel in the game. You have a map that at first may be confusing, but don't let this get you down. Just use it with your compass, and don't forget to jot down the extra notes when you find them. This helps fill out your map as time goes on. The game is short compared to most games. For some, one play through is all they will need. I personally will be playing it through again, in hopes of making different dialogue options and completing four achievements that I missed my first time through. Many were not happy with how the game finally ends. I actually quite liked it. It may not have been as EPIC as everyone anticipated, but it fit with the story. Everything tied together and you see where you fit into all of it. If you buy this game, do beware, the game is labeled as 'adults having adult conversations.' There are times where conversations get deep about the lives of you and Delilah, but for the most part, I did not come across anything said that was lued or crude. The game is labeled this way due to the amount of cussing used. At times, it can get really annoying. Your character even references once how much it is overly used. Personally, I am an adult, I work with adults, and we don't use language like that. So as a warning, for some this may be a shock or deterent from buying this game.  All in all, though, I recommend this game for any that want a story driven, non action based game. You will enjoy all of its moments: serenity, suspense, mystery, distress, comedy, life.

I'll preface this review by addressing the negative reviews first.    This is a short 'game' (I'll get to the quotation soon.) I started this in earnest at about 7:00pm and finished at about 11:00pm. This is in line with other reviews, saying the game itself clocks in under four hours long.    This is not your typical game. There's little action, no quick-time events, no rooty-tooty-point'-n'-shooty, no strategy, or sense of 'achievement'.     Many reviews complained about the abruptness of the ending, how it was 'anti-climactic' or 'a waste of time.'   Playing Firewatch, I found the game's highlight to be its characters. I think people were let down because of the ending because they came into it with their own preconceptions about the story. But it's not about the characters' story, it's about the story's characters. You really get to experience the setting through Henry's eyes, understand his thoughts, and see his back-and-forth with Delilah. Honestly, in the end, I didn't care about the story. I cared about the characters. You get relatable, believable characters, with superb voice-acting and very well-written dialogue. The game expertly flows between light-hearted joking and playful teasing, into paranoid anxiety and somber melancholy. I cannot speak highly enough of the writers, their dialogue and characters kept me and the girlfriend enthralled the whole way through. (She actually sat through the whole thing with me, from beginning to end! I don't know how many games can boast that kind of third-person retention!)  One of the other reviews I read put it pretty succinctly, the story has a bittersweet ending. I think other players went through it all, expecting some big payoff at the end, 'solve the mystery, get the girl, save the day.' But real life isn't always like that. Remember when I said I'd get to the part about this being a 'game'? I get that games should be an escape from real life, but this is sort of what makes Firewatch special; it's  not  a game that's meant to be  played , it's a   story   that's meant to be   experienced  .  Exploring the Wyoming wilderness, getting attached to the characters, and getting immersed into their world. That's what Firewatch is about, and I think it achieved its goal admirably.  - honk honk >(o )

Firewatch  is one of those games that I feel went through a tad few too many reworks. The world is fine, artstyle terrific, music pleasing, and I think it's definitely worth a buy, but there's lost potential here.  Delilah and Henry are overall both written terrifically, and I have nothing but praise for the dialogue and performance of their VAs. These two were organic, convincing, and overall just  human  in a way that many game characters fail. During the first few days their relationship developed in a sweet way, and I'd be content if the game focused on that the entire time. Nevertheless, the story presented always had a feeling of that there was supposed to be something more, past the point of an intentional red herring and into where it seems that the last arc especially was altered with not much time left in development.   What made the characters so great was dropped at the end - they no longer remained logically consistent and failed to behave as an emotional person would. The game spent a huge amount of time building up to a seemingly certain climax, only for it to never come. Events occurred, sure, but the reaction to them by both Henry and Delilah fell completely flat. The last scene suffered from the same issues.  Regardless,  Firewatch  succeeds in both developing and keeping player attention, and while I'd have preferred a different ending I also wouldn't say that the current spoils the game entirely.

I just finished my second playthrough of FIrewatch, so I thought that I'd describe each of my experiences with the game and then provide a general overview of pros/cons.  1st Adventure (Februrary, game release) Total Time: 7 hours   The first time you play Firewatch you can expect a plot with suspense, paranoia, and the possible jump scare. By no means is this a hardcore thriller though, I spent most of my first playthrough exploring the gorgeous environment in between working toward the main plot. The backbone of this game is the relationship that is developed through dynamic dialogue with Delilah, an off screen character. As you may have read many folks were disappointed with the 'lackluster' conclusion of the plot, but I found the openess of it to be liberating as a player. In essence the conclusion leaves you with more questions than answers, and in doing so forces you to think about the characters and their motivations even once you've finished the game (an objective that every game should aspire to, I think).  2nd Adventure (November, 10 months later) Total Time: 3 hours   The second playthrough was possibly more enjoyable for me than the first, even though I knew what was going to happen in the main plot. Going into this run I planned on enjoying the scenery and taking more pictures in game, the artwork is really that good (I now use these photos exclusively as my desktop backgrounds)! It was really gratifying to know the layout of the map based on past experience, the game feels more emersive when you intuitively know how to get around. Once again though, it was the dianamic dialogue and subtle plots that made for superb replay value. What you choose to say as a character directly affects which subplots you have access to, and I discovered many clues and stories this playthrough that I had assumed were simply unanswered/unfinished the first time.   I look forward to revisiting this game in 4 or 5 months, via a playthrough with developer/voice-actor commentary.  Pros: -Artwork/scenery -Dynamic dialogue -Emotional character plots -Judicious use of suspense and tension -Ambiant music that enhances mood -Open world -Special features -Replay value (occasionally)  Cons -Short highly structured plot -Limited endgame

Okay, this is the first time I've ever reviewed a game here.   I'm a career Wildland Firefighter, so you can probably guess that I was attracted to this game from the videos and pictures.   Now that that's out of the way, the only real cons I had were just a couple of details that weren't quite right [Slight spoiler, sort of] -the FF on the ship at the end, during evac... We don't wear SCBA in Wildland. The flipside of that, is that there is a lot of authenticity in this game. Many of the brocures and documents you find along the game are *almost* exact replicas of RL things, such as the fireline handbook (which even went as far as adding NWCG standards), fuel model publications, USFS prints and logos -hell even the terminology was for the most part correct. I was initially twitching a bit when he calls the pulaski an 'axe', but pleasantly surprised when he was quickly corrected.   Many aspects of this game are pretty realistic, even with the stylized graphics. Some others -not so much.   That's the technical stuff.   As for the actual depth of the game? Holy ♥♥♥♥. Legit first time I've ever played a game that was so emotionally involved with the player that I'd get that tingling, hair-on-the-neck-standing-up feeling. It felt super believable, yet keeping you on the edge of your seat guessing.   I'm sure I know where this story is going. Okay, maybe not, but I have a good theory... Well, that theory just got shattered all to hell. Damn, this is some crazy ♥♥♥♥... Maybe it's one of those good stories turned bad horror flick? Nope, and then the heartstrings.   I honestly feel that the creators did their homework on this piece. Are there technical things that weren't 100%? Sure. But then again, I've never played a game that's... well, a simulation of my career. So that's a first. Going into it, I expected a lot of mistakes and some of the more common misnomers to fly right up in my face, but was shocked when I started to notice just how much care was taken in creating this work of art.   The music is on par, the scenery is awesome, the story is amazing.   Do yourself a favor and buy this. Best money I've ever spent on steam.   Bonus: The ending credits remind me *so* much of some of my fondest memories, going on western fire detail. That little addition was the icing on the cake. Campo Santo just HAD to make me all nostalgic. I'm not going to ruin it for you, but when you get to that point, you'll see what I mean.   Short and simple: Buy it.

Firewatch is a difficult game to review. On one hand, I liked it personally, but on the other hand, it definitely won't appeal to everyone. Some people will even go as far as to consider it a 'walking simulator' similar to Dear Esther, as the game generally consists of you walking from one part of the forest to another while chatting with your supervisor over the walkie-talkie. However, there are still some mild adventure game elements present; you will need to obtain a few tools to reach certain areas that would otherwise be inaccessible, and you will need some orienteering skills to navigate the forest using a map and compass. Furthermore, you are constantly presented with multiple dialogue options during the radio conversations with your supervisor, which subsequently influences each character's tone when speaking to one another - although it has no effect on the major events of the story. I believe that it can actually be beneficial to maintain a certain degree of linearity in the plot because it becomes difficult to tell a compelling story when there are too many branching paths for the player to take. That being said, the game still presented an adequate amount of interactivity to keep me engaged.  The biggest criticism most people have of this game is that they were disappointed by the ending. You will often hear people say that the whole game maintained an aura of suspense leading up to the finale, but then the ending fell flat since they were expecting something crazier. You will also hear that, while the ending resolves the central mystery of the plot, it raises even more unanswered questions that are left open to the player's interpretation, and people wanted more of a sense of closure. I personally think that the developers intended for the game to end this way; Firewatch has a very strong theme of realism, so it would only make sense for the ending to follow suit. However, I will say that I sensed some budget difficulties as I witnessed the ending. I won't spoil anytihng, but I'll say there were certain elements that could have easily been added to the ending if the developers had either more time or money.  Speaking of realism, the voice acting in Firewatch is nothing short of excellent, and it makes the characters very believable. No matter which dialogue options you choose, you can always see why the characters respond to each other the way they do. To top it all off, the environments in this game are absolutely gorgeous; you will feel as though you are walking through a real forest in Wyoming. You can clearly tell that the development team poured a lot of heart into Firewatch, despite consisting of only 11 people. Still, I think $20 is a lot to ask for considering the game is only 4 or 5 hours long. It might be best to buy it duing a sale, but I'd still say it's worth your time.

I felt connected to the character while making decisions at the beginning of the game.  The mystery element that shows up towards the middle of the game had me on the edge of my seat trying to think of what was going on. I was immersed in the story until the final act.  After a big reveal in the story, I felt like it was an easy cop-out and that the last portion of the game was very rushed. The ending left me wanting more.  There was no conspiracy to the 'mystery'. My time spent talking to the other character seemed wasted. The game describes as 'the only other person you can talk with' and 'will you be able to keep a relationship while you are alone?'   In all, I enjoyed the game as an artistic experience rather than a game. I find it hard to believe that it's priced as high as it is when you can beat it in less than 3 hours. There is plenty of opportunity to explore, but it's not an overly expansive world, so you can only really add another 1 to 2 hours of gameplay by exploring. If there was a neutral rating on steam, I would choose that. I liked the game and would recommend it to someone who wants an artistic experience, but I also wouldn't recommend it based on the price.

Only being able to climb 'special rocks' when they let you, being obstructed by a small bush, etc not quite invisible wall, but nearly. Frequently running into these artificial restrictions is jaring and reminds you your a rat in the designers maze, not free roaming the wilds of Wyoming.  2: It became apparent that there was not much character animation or even characters in the game, so despite the narative telling you to watch out because someone (or bear) might jump out and attack you. You knew it wasn't going to happen as that would require character animation. This also meant the anti-climatic ending was predictable.  3: You have to answer Delilah, your radio companion and narative driver within a short time period, but despite it being a small walkie talkie, you cannot use the radio one handed (even though this is how it is animated), so no reading the map and talking. This mean Delilah becomes quite disruptive, a chore and you often just want her to be quite and let you get on with the task in hand.  I would recomend it for the wonderful look, clean style and atmosphere, but in truth it left me feeling frustrated that it kept clumsily breaking the immersive spell so much effort had been put into creating.  (spoiler alert) The naritive is also a disapointment, the voice acting is great, compelling, the story builds in drama, there is a raging out of control fire threatening, are you the innocent suspect in a double murder? you are about too confront your elusive tormentor and finally meet the delectable Delilah your partner in adventure and crime, and then, meh, nothing, no payoff.  Given all the hype this game has achieved, what was delivered underwhelmed.  You need to decide if $20 is good value for a 3 hour game with no real replay value.

Finally finished Firewatch. I ended up not getting to play the game when it first came out because of an issue with Unity and multiple gpu's. No points lost there, it was unrelated to Firewatch itself.   Once that was fixed, I have been tackling the game in 30-60 minute chunks. I took it slow and read all of the papers, picked everything up and generally spoke on the radio as much as possible. (Except during the height of my paranoia when I avoided talking to D several times).  The experience is very different than what I expected going in, however the marketing was vague and designed I think to attract people in an expected way to an expected story. What you actually end up getting is something I haven't experienced in many games, and I think it's something along the lines of really feeling connected to the emotions of the main character. In the end I can't tell if it was for the same  reasons , but I was definitely empathetic with the situation, and had paid enough attention to eek out a few final observations on everything that was left unsaid.   There is a sense of faux interactivity in this world - it is quite linear and there is no 'game'. This is not just a side effect of 'walking simulators', at least in Firewatch I believe it's quite intentionally done to put you as much as possible, into H's shoes.  If you haven't played the game yet and intend to, put your expectations aside and see what happens.

I greatly enjoyed the fourish hours I spent playing through this game. The near-walking-sim gameplay can be boring if not monotonous at times, but this isn't Rocket League. The gameplay isn't the focus, and the story is well capable of carrying the game. It's a twisting tale of spying and deception worthy of a mystery novel. A novel, however, would have lost two of Firewatch's greatest strengths (besides the story, of course).  One, it's gorgeous. It looks and sounds simply amazing. The visuals aren't gunning for photorealistic, and they don't have to. The game simply looks awesome, the sort of game where nearly any screenshot looks like concept art. The environment is pretty and well-designed, full of rolling hills, green plants, and rugged cliffs. The atmospheric effects combine with the haunting soundtrack (which plays at major plot points, Half-Life style) to bring the tense story to life, and the sound effects bring a surprising amount of realism to the slightly cartoony style.  The real reason to buy Firewatch, though, is the simultaneous isolation and connectedness brought about by its premise. You're in the deep woods, so people are few and far between. However, you have one connection to civilization: your radio, carried with you at all times. It is through this radio that Firewatch's story unfolds, and your developing relationship with the person on the other end is where the game really shines. Nearly every dialogue offers you a choice of words, and those words have a deep effect on your developing relationship, if not on the game's core storyline (which is fairly linear on its own). Every single dialogue choice is elaborated by some incredible voice acting work. The voices are relatable, believable, and really bring the two characters to life. And on the rare occasion that your radio fails you, you truly begin to feel alone.  I have only one real complaint with this game, and that is that it suffers from a few technical issues. The game's FPS varies wildly, and some scenes are quite obviously not optimized. I also managed to get into a situation where the game ceased to respond to keyboard inputs, forcing me to return to my previous save.  My last statement is one of cost: Firewatch has a very low price to gameplay ratio. I got it on sale, and well I thoroughly enjoyed it and would pay full price, you may not find 4 hours of gameplay to be worth $20. There is some replay value, but the story itself doesn't respond much to your input, only the subplot of your relationship with the one at the other end of the radio.  All in all, Firewatch was an enjoyable experience, and I highly recommend you try it. If you're on the fence about the price, go for it! You won't regret it.

Spoiler-free review: This game is absolutely worth the 19,99 euros. If you enjoy story telling games, then this is definitely for you. The voice acting is some of the best I have ever seen in the gaming industry, the cartoony graphics works particularly well for this game, and even though you RARELY see any other person in the game, the social interaction with Delilah through the radio comms is spectacular. Overall, this game is an emotional rollercoaster; joy, awe and sadness overwhelms you throughout the game.  I can definitely  recommend  this game to you all.  About the ending (SPOILERS):   A lot of people seem to be annoyed by the ending, calling it anticlimactic. Sure, they could have gone full conspiracy-mode for the ending, but I am glad they didn't. Instead of ending with the feeling of understanding and relief, you are left with the feeling of sorrow. You feel sorry for the kid, Brian, whose father forced him into trying climbing, leading to his death (Boy, during the credits, those pictures taken by Brian, they really kick you in the weak spot). You feel dissapointed about Delilah's desicion not to see you, after a whole summer of conversation about life. I have never played any game which made me geniunely feel this way - and it was an experience.    KUDOS TO THE DEV TEAM!

Firewatch lets you live through a pretty emotional experience through a first-person lens using a choose-your-own-dialogue narrative with a little bit of point-and-click adventure on the side. I missed a few early dialogue options before I realized that they have time-limited controls.   The game doesn't require much in the way of skill to navigate. Just an appreciation for good story and the curiosity to keep looking out for what comes next.   I'd recommend this to anybody.

Firewatch is one of those rare occurences that leaves you feeling a little off, but this is far from a bad thing. It seems as though many people are focusing on the graphics and while this is an important factor that makes the game more enjoyable, the graphics aren't the reason this game is so important. This game deals with a lot of adult themes in very adult ways through the conversation Henry has with Delilah. I talked to Delilah as much as possible throughout my three and a half hour playthrough and I wish it was more. The reason for this is because of Delilah's sarcast yet caring nature which made me fall in love with her. The dialogue between Delilah and Henry is some of the best written dialouge I've ever heard and sitting here post game it blows me away. The ending of the game is what has a lot of people on the edge about whether or not this game was good or even worth their time and money. This game is not supposed to make the player feel safe and comfortable. It was designed for the player to make difficult decisions that affect multiple different lives, and not all the options are happy ones. People might be dissapointed by the ending but thats life, it contributes to the adult themes I was talking about earlier. Everything isn't always going to work out. Some things will go wrong, but the player (or character) needs to find a way to control the damage and move on. This expirience is something that should not be ignored and everyone should play it and enjoy it. It deserves no less than a 10/10 Well done Campo Santo

Firewatch is a game about a man named Henry who took on a summer job to watch for fires in a national forest in Wyoming to temporarily leave behind some frustrations of life back home, who's only emotional and human lifeline is a female called Delilah on the other end of a radio.  Wow. Besides the flora rich environment, and the great pacing, this game packed some serious punch in the three hours of gameplay in its storyline. Henry is trying to escape some trouble back home with his wife who was diagnosed with a form of dementia, and he was no longer able to take care of her. His boss Delilah is the only other person who he has contact with throughout the game constantly. Feelings begin to fly and the two form a great relationship and friendship. Frelationship? I don't know. I digress.  What makes this game so great is the storyline. Many people were upset and could not get over the end (myself included) because it did not feel proper. It felt cut off, short, and very anticlimactic. However if you sit back and think about the process of the game and how Henry and Delilah progressed together and put two and two together about events that occurred (  H and D were paranoid about the potential Government employees spying on them, tapping into their radios frequency, listening to their conversations, which apparently was solidified when they thought the biologists camp was a monitoring station spying on them, but once H found out Ned was simply covering his end because of the death of his son, and making up everything as he thought they were out to get him, H and D suddenly realized everything they had done was out of human feelings of paranoia, and ultimately, for nothing.  ) you realize that it was simply basic human gut reactions. The final knife in the heart so to speak. We see ourselves in Henrys shoes, doing the exact same thing, and when everything we worked for was taken away (   Delilah leaving us and not staying, never meeting up like she wanted when she told you over the radio when she was flirting  ) we feel hurt, and betrayed, and confused. Almost like a 'Real life simulator 2016'.   Campo Santo really drew into human feelings and interaction in this game and really hit the nail on the head. I'm still not over it and I feel an emotional pull to this game, which is very hard to come by these days. I absolutely recommend this game. It will put you on the feel train even if you didn't buy the ticket.

TL:DR This is a brilliant atmospheric game with beatiful scenery and some great interaction between the two main characters. As much as I liked it i wouldnt recommend buying at full price but worth buying if on sale.  Full version: Firewatch is a great atmospheric game with some beautiful looking scenery. You play as Henry who takes up a post at a firewatch tower in the Wyoming wilderness for the summer season. Henry's only human contact in this isolated environment is with Delilah, who is a colleague working in a neighbouring but distant tower and all Henrys interaction with her is through a walkie talkie radio. As you wander about the wilderness completing task you'll chat to Delilah via this radio with different dialogue options. The voice acting is brilliant and really makes the back and forth between Henry and Delilah is the games highlight.   The games environment is fantastic. Its features some breathtaking scenery and captures that feeling of isolation perfectly. Its great how the mood can fluctuate between peaceful and really tense out in that environment.   The games story is also quite good as early on in Henrys stay at the tower something starnge begins to unfold and Henry and Delilah try to get to the bottom of it.  Good points: - The interaction between Henry and Delilah is this games highlight and its helped by the fantastic voice actors for both characters. - The scenery and atmosphere in this game is incredible and it really captures of the feeling of being almost alone in the remote wilderness. -It has a great story which is great in the build up even if the ending was a bit lacking  Bad points: -The game does feel a bit padded out at times with long treks through the wilderness but exploring that beautiful scenery makes it less of a chore

Firewatch does this, the story flows incredibly nicely and it has some sharp hooks.  The games narrative also has the ability to drum everyday normal things to epic proportions, and that works perfectly to get you the player sucked into the entire story. Firewatch's story is short, sweet, and grim in the sense of how it ballons yourself up into near fantasy levels only to have that ideas of grandure come crashing down to the grim reality of everyday life and the poor choices people make.  If you've got a free evening, and want to experience a beautiful story of mystery, dealing with life, all set in a beautifully stylized forrest then Firewatch is the game for you.

This one is difficult. Let's just concentrate on pros and cons. + Graphics - the game looks great. I love the artstyle and the atmosphere it creates. + Dialogue - the voice actors are good and I especially like Henry's voice.  ~ The story is interesting and builds up nicely. But in the end, it turns out to be rather mediocre.  - Replay value: none. I restarted some days a few times, choosing different dialog options. The outcome of the dialogs were the same, in most cases, even Delilah's replies were the same. Once you know the story, there's no reason for you to play again. Unless, of course, you want to just walk around. - Content: I finished the game in 2.4 hours. That includes restarting a few days or restoring former saves.  Summary: is the game worth buying? Well... you can see the effort they put into it. But I wouldn't spent 20€ on it. Wait for a sale, then go for it.

I really enjoyed this game!   I saw that it had a few reviews that weren't happy with the ending, but I thought it was resolved just enough. I'd rather have a bit of openness to fill in myself when it comes to people's personal struggles and character development, so I was quite happy with it!  If you are a lover of character development and a good story, you should enjoy this. Just keep in mind, it's the kind of game that you sit back and play leisurely. Brilliant game. Gorgeous imagery throughout, and both the writing and voice acting were spot on. It's not a game of skill at all, it's all about exploration and managing a tenuous relationship. I feel like there were some unanswered questions, but I do feel that it fit the game and theme. It's also relatively short, it took me just under 5 hours, but I'm OK with that too. I picked it up on sale, and it was well worth it.  A lot of gamers decry the rise of so-called 'walking simulators', but generally I love them. Dear Esther, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, Gone Home, and now Firewatch have each in their own slightly different way, been some of my most memorable and affecting experiences in gaming. Of those, Dear Esther is the thinnest (you really just walk along a path while listening to narration), and Firewatch is probably the deepest (due to its adaptive relationship mechanics and genuine exploration), but all are worth playing.

Firewatch is a great game, but more importantly, has one of the most profound narrative experiences I've had from a game.  Graphically, there's a lot to love, The art style is fantastic. It gives the world such a beautiful, rich and colorful feel. And my goodness, is the world incredible to look at. The lighting effects, the varied scenery in form of trees, grass, water, rock, all gel together to form a beautifully scenic visual experience as a medium to experience the rich narrative of the game. Nothing to complain about the visuals of this game, simply splendid.  As for the gameplay aspects, there really wasn't much in the way of anything interesting. Exploring is enjoyable because of the rich visuals and dialogue, but gameplay is rather uninspired. It mainly takes the form of walking around and button presses to one-dimensionally interact with the environment (such as tap a button to chop a tree, open a supply crate, grab an item, open a door, etc). Simple traversal through areas is really the main form of gameplay. The best thing I can say about the gameplay is how much it evokes the sense of actually experiencing a nature hike, given the beautiful environments and just the organicness of using a compass and map to navigate. That just makes it feel so much more real It's a really immersive exploration experience.  I absolutely loved the character building of Henry and Delilah. One of the most amazing and meaningful developments of characters relationship I've ever seen in a game. The dialogue was fantastic. Fun, witty, extremely well voiced acted (probably the 'most real' I've heard in any game I've played), and most importantly incredibly natural and immersive. But even more so than the dialogue, both of these characters simply bled depth and their relationship was given one of the most complex and well thought out stories I've ever experienced.   It's amazing how well Henry and Delilah complement each other in the story. Both characters are clearly flawed, but more specifically, are shown to be running away from their problems. They are both in the same boat. Henry was unable to handle the situation with his wife (who has dementia) and took a firewatch job to escape the pressure. Likewise, Delilah had left her behind relationship with her boyfriend after his brother died, failing to be there for him and being afraid of facing him. This puts Henry and Delilah in a position to really understand and connect with each other, which can be seen happening as they get very close with each other. The truth is, they've found comfort and solace in each other as they share their past experiences and find out just how similarly they deal with their problems: running away, alcoholism, isolation, and avoidance. Their relationship blossoms because of this, and this makes the dynamic between the characters truly meaningful.  What is interesting as well, is the development of each character differs in how they deal with their problems throughout the story. Delilah is shown to be undoubtedly still running away. She speaks only through a radio with Henry, seemingly reluctant to meet him. She lies about having involvement in the incident with the missing girls in the police report, hoping to avoid the police. Most importantly, she decides not to wait for Henry when evacuating, despite his wishes to see her. She's been avoiding and running away from confrontation her whole life, and it really shows in the progress of the game. Now take Henry, who develops differently. Henry makes an effort to stop running away. He takes the initiative to investigate the strange events occurring around him. He tries to fix his problems. He even seems to stop drinking when he's on the job. The fact that he is the one doing the work really goes to show that unlike Delilah, he's really trying to change himself. Although these two characters come from the same position and grow close because of the connection they share, the difference in how they deal with their problems in the course of Firewatch really shows just how much they contrast each other as well.  In the end, the evacuation really reinforces the idea that both characters are still running away. But this time they are running away together instead of alone, as they've grown to understand and connect with each other. However the difference in how they are conveyed is that Henry is shown to still be trying to tie loose ends, by making an effort to meet with Delilah when they evacuate. It's easy to see that Henry is trying to stop running away. Delilah in contrast however, is unwilling to wait for Henry, and simply wants escape from her responsibilities, instead of looking to face them.  As can be seen, the relationship between Henry and Deliliah is really the centrepiece of the game. It's so much more complex and intricate than what most people who play the game give it credit for.   I've heard a lot of people call the ending disappointing, because 'nothing really happened or was resolved'. But I think people give it flak for the ending because they judged the game as a mystery-suspense story. It's not one. It's a drama. The mystery arc was simply a plot device for the development of Henry and Deliliah's story arc. The mystery car was not meant to be resolved because that's not what the game was focused on. People were expecting it to be, and felt empty when it wasn't, which is likely a prime reason for why there was an air of disappointment surrounding the ending. But it's not about the mystery story. It's all about Henry and Delilah and the progression of their stories and characters. It's about showing a bonding between two people, born out of the similarities between who they are how they deal with problems. It's about studying character interactions and development.  If I had a complaint, it would be that the game didn't really seem to fully 'complete' Henry and Delilah's character arcs, as they didn't progress as characters all that much and never really 'resolved' any of their problems and flaws. But I couldn't honestly expect a full character narrative, given that this game is only $20 and has only 4 hours of gameplay. It was simply meant to *show* character and relationship dynamics and how characters deal with problems and provide a thoughtful perspective on human interaction, thought, and behavior. Definitely a game I enjoyed more when I took the time to really think about it.

Firewatch is a pleasant experience the whole way through, the visuals are incredible, textures are extrememly detailed, and the using of lighting is phenominal. the gameplay keeps you interested and invested, as hiking around the forest isn't a thing the game forces you through, with 'waypoints' or lines that show up on the ground telling you where to go. you rely on a map and compass to get you to where you need to go and it can be very easy to get lost if not paying attention.  The environment also starts to feel familiar while playing, and you start to rely less and less on your compass and map to go places, as you recognise where you are and which way is the right way, as the environment do not feel 'samey' in any way, and landmarks and area's are very easily recognisable and memorable, making the game feel dynamic and leaving the player feeling in control.  the dialoge and story telling is one of kind when it comes to videogames, the writting is very very well done, as the story basically contains only 2 character (Henry and Delilah), you never feel bored with them or feel like things are becoming stale, you find yourself invested in the characters and never ever feel like skipping dialoge. you can feel the emotions in the actors dialoge and it never feels like simply 'an actor saying lines'. and being able to walk through the forest while simultaneously talking to Delilah is easy to do and is very fun and dynamic. press shift to bring up the radio, scroll to the one you wanna say, let go of shift, which is never interrupted by other actions done while exploring. your actions and movements feel like part of the environment, and you always feel connected with your surroundings, like your actually in and moving through a forest, rather then 'a player camera looking around a built environment'. it all feels very natural.  I know this was said earlier but the visuals are truely stunning, I typically don't tend to pay attention to graphics in games but you really cannot help but just stop and think 'jesus this beautiful' while playing this game, as well as how detailed textures are, as in most games I find when you zoom in on objects in the environment (books, vehicles, etc) you start to notice pixels or things poorly done with the texture, but in Firewatch zooming in on objects really proves to the player how much the devs cared about keeping Firewatch as immersive for the player as they could avoiding anything that could take the player out of it pixels are rarely seen and objects feel real. at points in the game you'll come across such stunning visuals that you'll feel like this should be something to take a photo of, which the game devs clearly realized by the fact the game hands you a camera and you can stop and take photo's whenever you like, and the photo's are showcased in the credits, which I felt was a very very nice touch.  the game itself is not long, which I appreciated but was also disappointed with both at the same time, because the devs didn't try and force the game to be long by forcing you to do unnecessary tasks or making paths longer then they needed to be. it told a nice concise story and didn't over stay it's welcome.
