***  IF ANYONE WANTS TO PLAY THIS GAME, LOOK AWAY BECAUSE THIS CONTAINS SPOILERS  ***     Like many people, I enjoyed the game but the ending was super underwhelming. People make the argument that it's trying to show that it's all life. It's disappointing, you aren't special (how Henry and Delilah weren't actually being tracked by the government), and showing how people deal with their problems and fears (by running away from them). I feel like this was just lazy, sloppy, and felt rushed. I wanted to see Delilah. I wanted to see Julia, I wanted to see Ned. I wanted to see Ron and Dave (what even came of these guys? Literally nothing). I wanted to see myself. But most of all, I'd have liked a different final act all together. I was ♥♥♥♥ing terrified playing this game. When I showed up to the already wrecked campsite of the teenagers (who magically appear alive at the end of the game, whoopee) it started feeling eerie. Then the notes of the walkie talkie conversations. Then I started to doubt Delilah even more. She was just someone up in a tower so far away that I'd never seen and that I just began to immediately trust, and that started to wean. Then when I was hunting the trail of the hunters I was just so ♥♥♥♥ing creeped out- it was legitimately scary. Don't even get me started on the cave near the end. The ideal ending for me would have been for all the missing people (Ned, Brian, the teens, Mitch (the random dude who went missing around the lake- the ♥♥♥♥ happened to this guy anyway? They've never said anything more about it)) all of those missing people were in a government facility in the cave where they were tortured and being tested cruelly and it was gonna be dark, disturbing, and creepy. The game could have been horrifying. Instead, in the course of five minutes it's revealed that it's just crazy ol Ned and the whole thing doesn't matter and then BOOM the ending and you're disappointed. I'll give the dead Brian good value for being eerie, sad, depressing, and great objectively for the story.        Anyway, the game was good but it lost all scariness once the Ned reveal came about, and when I beat it, I actually completely forgot I'd been scared at all when playing, that's how much it was ruined. The game wasn't meant to be scary, and I've played and watched many scary games and movies which don't get to me what-so-ever, but this one did. The paranoia of being alone and feeling watched made my skin crawl. When I had to go the creek near the scout camp after D was acting quite strange over the radio, I could swear I heard rustles in the bushes and it was freaking me out so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ much. It may very well have been the scariest moment in any game in my life.      All in all, the game's ending could have used a lot of work, but I don't regret my purchase, my time spent playing, and I'd definitely recommend it to friends.

I read a small article in a Hungarian blog about the best games in 2016. At least according to the blogger. I was happy to see unknown titles not the usual AAA ones. One of the titles was this game. Read few sentences, watched the trailer and looked for Firewatch on Steam.  Let's see the game. I do not want to spoiler anything about its story so I just summarize my feelings.  CONS: - The play time/price factor is not very good. One can purchase a game with much more play time for that amount of money. - I'm quite a fan of role-playing games. Although this is not an RPG, but it's mostly dialogue driven and I cannot play a lawful-good character. There are many choices but all point to almost the same direction and you cannot be, cannot play the good guy in shine armor on a white horse. Even when you try to act as good as possible the story does not let it happen. I understand that the developer tried to minimize the characters, events, interactions but dispite of all that, I missed the opportunity. - The story is written. No matter how hard you try to change the main narrative, it remains the same.  PROS: - The game created such a unique atmosphere that I hardly noticed how time passed - The dialogues are well written, they enlighten events from the past - The player can easily immerse into the game's beautiful world. I sometimes went hiking in the woods just for fun and to take some pictures of the wildlife. - At the end, for $15 the authors can send you hardcopies of your shots, so try to make really amazing pictures.  All in all, I liked the game, I recommend the game even if you could purchase it on a sale. For me it is like a point&click adventure game in a charming, fascinating environment. Do not expect complex riddles, just live the life of a not-completely-ordinary man in the wilderness.

I love a good story, and I love a good game. This has both. Immersive storytelling, top quality voice acting, and an experience that is unlike most games of today.   It's fairly short (<8 hours), but somehow that seems fitting for a game of this magnitude. I bought Firewatch on sale at $12, and for what is essentially the price of a modern day movie ticket, this game is absolutely worth it.  You're put in the shoes of a man who's life has gone astray. His personal relationship has fallen apart due to circumstances out of his control, and he is immensely troubled. He decides to escape into nature for a summer, only to find himself in the midst of mysterious events that test his sanity and his convictions as he develops a repertoire with his supervisor, the only contact he has.  Yes, it's a walking simulator, but one in which you're in charge of how your character responds to the supervisor on the other end of the walkie talkie. And it's one in which you constanly guessing what will happen next, all alone in the beautiful, desolate nature of Wyoming.  I would love to have more games like this, especially it they develop on the 'your choices' affecting the storyline. If I had to knock the game, it'd be that your choices don't seem like they have much of an impact.

First of all let me say I knew nothing about this game going into except for the fact it was on sale. Secondly, lets dive on into it.  Pros:  1) Beautiful scenery. Thats literally the first thing you'll notice about the game and its spectacular.  2) Relatable character. Even if you have never been in Henry's shoes, you can easily feel empathy and understanding for him. 3) Steady pacing. The game moves at a relatively steady pace, not too fast where it feels like you're at the end already, and not too slow where you have no idea where the hell the end is. 4) You get to have choices, which for me is a personal pro.   Cons: 1) The choices you make don't seem to impact the game at all. (This can be a con if you feel like they should which is obvious, but for me I didn't really care if my choices mattered or not, I just chose with what I felt during the story.) 2) The only person you see is at the end, you don't even get to see Henry or other people (For some this isn't a con, but I felt like If I was going to relate to a character I wanted to at least know what I looked like)  3) The story is HELLA short. I wanted more out of this game because it was so good, but sadly the story is short. 4) The ending really didn't satisfy me. (This is commonly seen throughout reviews for this game, simply because it's true.) The ending makes sense, but it's also not as satisfying as it could've been.  All in all, the game is great and I'd recommend this to anybody. It's thrilling, easy to follow, and beautiful. At least a solid 9/10.

If you expect big action or fast paced gameplay then you should search somewhere else. But Firewatch delivers a beautiful story, with a lot feelings at a slow pace. There are no big decisions to make and the fate of the world doesn't depend on your actions. In Firewatch you enjoy little moments, it really is great in setting the mood with a quiet somewhat melancholic tone at first wich develops into a paranoid feeling, wich is often broken up with some good comic relief that mostly comes from the conversations with D.  It takes about 4-5 hours to get through the story, wich is short, but I felt like that was some quality time and somehow justified the price of 12 € (wich is about as much as a cinema visit around here). Even if Firewatch is the real 'walking simulator' it never felt boring, I had fun exploring the Forest and thanks to your walkie talkie it always stays interesting. They did a great job on that, I somhow even felt that I missed the chatter when it wasn't possible due to some reason. The soundtrack/sounddesign does a very good job helping you to get in the mood and adds a lot to this game.  The flow of the gameplay is mostly unhindered. Sometimes the controlls could be a bit more precise, like standing on the wrong place in front of a fallen over tree to walk over it. But it isn't that bad. The graphic style is really nice, but could have used some polish here and there I was noticing way to much texture seams on rocks and whatnot.   I would buy it again. Lovely crafted game, with a deep, heartwarming story and a great feeling to it.

I've never written a review before, but I've decided to do so for this game to express how deeply dissapointed I am with it.   I thought the game was a great idea and provided a mysterious experience I could share with my girlfriend-- and at the very beginning it had us guessing--but only at the very beginning. Honestly, a mystery story is only really a mystery when there's more than one suspect. This game mentions 4 people, one of them is you, one of them is your ally, and one is incapable of the actions that are 'mysterious'. Right from minute one you know how it ends if you spend any time thinking it.  A casual story game with minimal mechanical gameplay is usually only good when the story is emersive and thoughtful. Instead I solved the mystery in 15 minutes and waited 3 hours to NOT receive any closure or be left with any question; it ends exactly how it started: depressing and simplistic.   I would recommend this game to anyone who's never played video games before because it's extremely forgiving (i.e. you can't die, your decisions aren't that impactful at all despite the time limit for responses and the large amount of them). I would NOT recommend this to anyone looking for a real story that makes the player think.

It's pretty great, although you need to be aware of what Firewatch is. The voicework is really enjoyable and there are plenty of little details to pay attention to and put together if you want. I'd say its definitely worth the price of a DVD with a good movie; you'll get about 3-4 hours of content from it (a bit more if you delve into extras), so it's best to play it in one sitting and really get into it.  Oh, and you have an option of disabling the GPS showing your position on the map. Do it. Enjoy the landmarks. Navigate yourself.
